z:row.TitlePrimary: A Machine for Fretting Wear Testing of Plasma Surface-Modified Materials
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SANDSTROM, PW, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,1410 W JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Microscopic damage caused by fretting wear is of significant concern in many engineering applications. We report the design and performance of a versatile fretting wear testing machine that uses an electromagnetic actuator under closed-loop control to provide a constant slip amplitude over a wide frequency range. The machine is equipped with a mechanism that allows for gradual sample contact and precise relocation of the stylus. An innovative method for monitoring frictional forces during the course of a test is incorporated. The machine has been successfully applied to materials treated by three types of plasma surface modification: nitrogen ion implantation, thin film alloy deposition and diamond-like carbon film deposition.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A Study of the Relationship between Wear Rate and Nitrogen Concentration Profile and Application to Plasma Source Ion-Implanted Ti-6al-4v Alloy
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, A, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen implantation by plasma source ion implantation was conducted on Ti-6Al-4V alloy. The wear performance was characterized using a pin-on-disk wear tester and an alpha-step profilometer. Nitrogen concentration depth profiles of implanted samples were studied using a scanning Auger microprobe. It is found that the lowest wear rate in the implanted zone corresponds to the nitrogen concentration peak. By varying the target temperature, the nitrogen concentration profile was engineered to achieve a better wear behavior. The pin-on-disk wear data agree with the expected result.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of Ion Species Ratio in the Plasma Source Ion-Implantation Process
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: TANG, BY, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Ion species and their ratios in nitrogen, oxygen, and argon plasmas in the plasma source ion implantation process have been determined with a simple and low-cost measurement system. The measured ion species ratio in the nitrogen plasma was used as an input parameter for the computer simulation code transport and mixing from ion irradiation to predict the atomic composition-depth profile. Comparison between the code results and data derived from Auger analysis for a nitrogen-implanted Ti-6Al-4V alloy showed good agreement. In this article, the design, performance, and possible future improvements regarding the resolution of this measurement system will be discussed.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dose and Dose-Rate Effects on the Structure of Methane Plasma Source Ion-Implanted 304 Stainless-Steel
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Materials Science and Engineering A-Structural Materials Properties Microstructure and Processing
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, J, ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,1410 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Type 304 stainless steel was treated by methane plasma source ion implantation. The effects of implantation dose and dose rate on the microstructure have been investigated. The implantation was carried out at a target bias of -30 keV, Two different doses: 1.5 x 10(17) and 3 x 10(17) atoms cm-2, and three dose rates: 3.4, 6.8 and 15 muA cm-2 were used. Higher doses and lower dose rates favor the formation of crystalline structure in the form of Fe2C (at 3.4 muA cm-2), or a mixture of Fe2C and possibly Fe3C and/or (Fe, Cr)7C3 (at 6.8 muA cm-2). Higher dose rates and lower doses favor the development of an amorphous structure. The mechanism of phase transformation in the implanted layer and its dependence on dose and dose rate are discussed.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A Study of Nitrogen Ion-Implanted Ti-6al-4v Eli by Plasma Source Ion-Implantation at High-Temperature
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MATERIALS PARK; SUBSCRIPTIONS SPECIALIST CUSTOMER SERVICE, MATERIALS PARK, OH 44073-0002
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, A, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation target temperatures are estimated by measuring the diffusion coefficient of nitrogen in the target and subsequently deducing the temperature. The diffusion coefficient is measured by comparing measured nitrogen concentration profiles to Monte Carlo simulations. Auger results indicated the affected zone of implantation is about 0.5 mum thick. Surface Knoop hardness improved from 400 to 900 (for 1-g applied load). Wear behavior was studied using a pin-on-disk wear tester. The wear data show a factor of 30 increase in wear lifetime (1 mum wear depth was chosen as the failure criterion). Comparison shows that the wear behavior of Ti-6Al-4V ELI (extra low interstitial) is as good as that of cobalt-chromium alloy, another candidate for surgical applications.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: 1982, ASTM F73282 ANTTILA A, 1983, J APPL PHYS, V42, P495 BLACK J, 1990, J BONE JOINT SURG AM, V72, P126 CHEN A, 1990, J MATER ENG, V12, P299 CONRAD JR, 1987, J APPL PHYS, V62, P4591 CONRAD JR, 1987, J APPL PHYS, V62, P777 CONRAD JR, 1988, SURF COAT TECH, V36, P927 CONRAD JR, 1989, J APPL PHYS, V65, P1707 DAVISON JA, 1990, T ORTHOP RES SOC, V36, P460 HAN SH, 1990, NUCL INSTRUM METH B, V45, P701 QIU X, 1988, SEP C P 1988 AIME FA QIU X, 1989, OCT ASM C WEAR CORR WOODMAN JL, 1983, J BIOMED MATER RES, V17, P655 WOODMAN JL, 1984, J ORTHOPAED RES, V1, P421; NR: 14; TC: 3; J9: J MATER ENG PERFORM; PG: 4; GA: KM854

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear Improvement Evaluation of Nonhomogeneous Surface Modified Materials
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, A, UNIV WISCONSIN,PLASMA AIDED MFG ENGN RES CTR,1410 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Quantitative evaluation of the improvement of wear properties due to surface modification is complicated by the fact that these properties vary as the modified layer is penetrated. Different methods of evaluation of the same wear test results can yield different or even contrary conclusions. In order to evaluate wear behavior correctly, a wear model that accounts for depth-dependent wear rates is developed and applied to four typical wear tests. It is found that under fixed wear test conditions, the evaluation of wear in surface modified materials depends markedly on the final depth of penetration. This is in contrast to the case of homogeneous materials, where the comparison of the wear behaviour of different materials is largely independent of wear depth. An improvement factor is introduced as the basic quantity for evaluating the wear improvement provided by surface modification. The prediction of the improvement factor from a basic tribology test is carried out for nitrogen ion-implanted Ti-6Al-4V specimens.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structure and Wear Properties of Carbon Implanted 304-Stainless Steel using Plasma Source Ion-Implantation
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, J, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Methane plasma source ion implantation was used to implant carbon ions into 304 stainless steel. This paper examines the effects of high voltage pulse repetition rate on the structure and wear properties of implanted samples. The implantations were carried out at a target bias of -30 keV to a dose of 3 x 10(17) atoms cm-2. Three repetition rates (42 Hz, 87 Hz and 126 Hz) were used. At low repetition rate, a carbon coated-implanted surface forms, while only an implanted surface is produced at high repetition rates. Metastable phases were observed and identified, and the microstructure at the surface was observed to be dependent on the chosen implantation parameters. Fe2C formed in the implantation layer which is produced at 42 Hz. Smaller size Fe2C and other forms of carbides (possibly Fe3C and/or (Cr, Fe)7C3) formed in samples implanted at 87 Hz. An increase in repetition rate to 126 Hz produced a shallower amorphous implantation layer. Possible explanations of phase formation mechanisms are given. Wear resistance of all the implanted samples was improved, with the coated-implanted sample produced at 42 Hz showing the greatest improvement. The mechanism of wear was observed to change from an adhesive mode to a mild abrasive mode after implantation.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: 1979, JCPDS INT CTR DIFFRA CONRAD JR, 1987, J APPL PHYS, V62, P4591 CONRAD JR, 1988, SURF COAT TECH, V36, P927 DEARNALEY G, 1978, THIN SOLID FILMS, V54, P215 DRAKO VM, 1982, RADIAT EFF, V66, P101 FOLLSTAEDT DM, 1989, MATER RES SOC S P, V140, P133 HAN SH, 1989, THESIS U WISCONSIN M HIRVONEN JK, 1978, J VAC SCI TECHNOL, V15, P1662 HUBLER GK, 1985, NUCL INSTRUM METH B, V7, P151 POPE LE, 1988, SURF COAT TECH, V36, P361 TREUTLER CPO, 1981, THIN SOLID FILMS, V79, P201 YOST FG, 1983, THIN SOLID FILMS, V107, P287; NR: 12; TC: 27; J9: SURF COAT TECH; PG: 9; GA: JW420

z:row.TitlePrimary: Use of Nitrogen-Implanted Chromium Overcoat for Improving the Durability of Thin-Film Magnetic Media
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MATERIALS PARK; SUBSCRIPTIONS SPECIALIST CUSTOMER SERVICE, MATERIALS PARK, OH 44073-0002
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AKASH MEMORIES CORP,SAN JOSE,CA. UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.; MULLER, DE, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT MAT SCI & ENGN,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A feasibility study of the use of nitrogen-implanted chromium asa protective overcoat for thin-film magnetic media was undertaken. Computer hard disks that were pre-sputtered with chromium were implanted with nitrogen using the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) process to produce a chromium nitride containing layer approximately 25 nm thick. Elemental concentration-depth profiles were determined with a scanning Auger microprobe. The presence of chromium nitride in the implanted layer was verified by examination of the broad scan of the Auger spectra. The durability of the PSII-treated hard disks relative to those with a standard carbon overcoat has been characterized with nanohardness, pin-on-disk and thin-film head-on-disk wear tests. A vibrating sample magnetometer was used to evaluate the magnetic properties of the disks. It has been demonstrated that PSII processing has the potential to im rove the durability of hard disks without any significant reduction in the magnetic properties.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: 1978, ANSI B461 AM NAT STA 1991, AKASHIC MEMORIES JUL, V1 1991, ANN REPORT U WISCONS ARNOLDUSSEN TC, 1986, P IEEE, V74 BHUSHAN B, 1990, TRIBOLOGY MECHANICS CHEN A, 1990, J MATER ENG, V12, P299 CHU MY, 1990, TRIBOLOGY MECHANICS, V7, P9 CONRAD JR, 1987, J APPL PHYS, V62, P4591 CONRAD JR, 1989, 4764394, US CONRAD JR, 1990, J VAC SCI TECHNOL, V4, P3146 DEARNALEY G, 1983, THIN SOLID FILMS, V107, P315 HAN SH, 1990, NUCL INSTRUM METH B, V45, P701 HERMAN H, 1981, NUCL INSTRUM METHODS, V182, P887 MARCHON B, 1989, TRIBOLOGY MECHANICS, V6, P71 MARCHON B, 1990, IEEE T MAGN, V26, P2670 MARCHON B, 1991, IEEE T MAGN, V27, P5160 MULLER D, 1991, UNPUB PALMETSHOFER L, 1989, MAT SCI ENG A-STRUCT, V114, P173 PETERS R, 1991, THESIS U WISCONSIN M PETHICA JB, 1983, PHILOS MAG A, V48, P593 SINGER IL, 1980, J VAC SCI TECHNOL, V17, P327 SIOSHANSI P, 1987, MATER SCI ENG, V90, P373 TORNG CJ, 1990, J MATER RES, V5, P2490 TOWNSEND PD, 1976, ION IMPLANTATION SPU WEIST C, 1987, MATER SCI ENG, V90, P399 WHITE RL, 1990, MATER RES SOC S P, V188 YANG M, 1991, IEEE T MAGN, V27, P5157; NR: 27; TC: 5; J9: J MATER ENG PERFORM; PG: 5; GA: JV732

z:row.TitlePrimary: Nitrogen Plasma Source Ion-Implantation of Aisi S1 Tool Steel
z:row.Keyword: SURFACE MODIFICATION|METALS|Engineering, Industrial|Engineering, Manufacturing|Materials Science, Multidisciplinary
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: REDSTEN, AM, UNIV WISCONSIN,PLASMA SOURCE ION IMPLANTAT PROGRAM,835 ENGN RES BLDG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Significant economic savings can be achieved by improving the wear lifetime of precision manufacturing tools through nitrogen-ion implantation. This near-ambient temperature, surface modification process preserves dimensional integrity and surface finish while eliminating delamination problems that are often associated with overlay coatings. Conventional ion implantation is a line-of-sight process which requires elaborate manipulation and masking to uniformly implant components of complex shapes. A recently developed process, plasma source ion implantation (PSII). circumvents this line-of-sight restriction and makes ion implantation more attractive economically. In this article. the effects of PSII of nitrogen at a target bias of 50 kV, to a dose of 0.3 X 10(18) atoms/cm2 on the surface microstructure and mechanical properties of AISI S1 tool steel are presented.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear Corrosion - Separation of the Components of Corrosion and Wear
z:row.Keyword: CATHODIC PROTECTION|CORROSION RATE|DEPASSIVATION|EROSION|EROSION-CORROSION|PASSIVITY|REPASSIVATION|SURGICAL TI-6AL-4V|ION-IMPLANTATION|Materials Science, Multidisciplinary|Metallurgy & Metallurgical Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: HOUSTON; 1440 SOUTH CREEK DRIVE, HOUSTON, TX 77084-4906
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: ABUZRIBA, MB, UNIV WISCONSIN,COLL ENGN,1509 UNIV AVE,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: An apparatus has been designed that permits separation of the wear and corrosion components of wear corrosion. A loaded ruby ball describes a circular track on a sheet specimen in a corrosion environment, with and without cathodic protection applied to the specimen to produce wear and wear corrosion, respectively. Profilometer traces of the tracks measure the metal removed in the two cases. Preliminary results on type 304 stainless steel demonstrate the validity of the technique.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surface Modification of Ti-6a1-4v Surgical Alloy by Plasma Source Ion-Implantation
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) was applied to Ti-6Al-4V surgical alloy to improve its tribological properties. Nitrogen implantation at room temperature produced an improvement in wear resistance. Implantation at an elevated temperature (approximately 600-degrees-C) resulted in a substantially thicker modified surface layer with sustained wear resistance. The best results were obtained by a two-step process wherein elevated temperature implantation was followed by room temperature implantation. The tribological properties resulting from this two-step process surpassed those of the Co-Cr alloy and were comparable with those obtained by ion nitriding. The base material properties remained unchanged after the PSII treatments. The surface properties were characterized using low-load microhardness measurements, pin-on-disk wear testing and Auger spectroscopy.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison between Conventional and Plasma Source Ion-Implanted Femoral Knee Components
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: CHEN, A, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen ion implantation of Ti-6Al-4V knee joint femoral components was carried out by both plasma source ion implantation (PSII), a non-line of sight technique, and conventional beamline implantation. Implantation using the PSII process was performed on a flat sample as well as a 2 x 2 square array of components to demonstrate batch processing capability. The retained dose of the flat sample and at different locations on the implanted components was measured by a scanning auger microprobe (SAM). The variation in dose of the PSII treated component was found to be within the SAM error, while the dose at one location on the beamline implanted component was found to be significantly low. For the beamline case, the SAM results show good agreement with the PC profile computer simulation, which includes the angular dependence of sputtering.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of Electron-Emission due to Energetic Ion-Bombardment in Plasma Source Ion-Implantation
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SHAMIM, MM, UNIV WISCONSIN,ENGN RES CTR PLASMA AIDED MFG,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: An experimental procedure has been developed to measure electron emission due to energetic ion bombardment during plasma source ion implantation. Spherical targets (radius = 2 cm) of copper, stainless steel, graphite, titanium alloy (Ti-6Al-4V) and aluminum alloy (6061) were biased negatively to 20, 30, and 40 kV in argon and nitrogen plasmas. A Langmuir probe was used to detect the propagating sheath edge and a Rogowski transformer was used to measure the current to the target. The measurements of electron emission coefficients compare well with those measured under similar conditions [B. Szapiro and J. J. Rocca, J. Appl. Phys. 65, 3713 (1989)].

z:row.TitlePrimary: Influence of Temperature on Nitrogen Ion-Implantation of Incoloy Alloys 908 and 909
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Materials Science and Engineering A-Structural Materials Properties Microstructure and Processing
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LAUSANNE 1; PO BOX 564, 1001 LAUSANNE 1, SWITZERLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: XIE, L, UNIV WISCONSIN,PLASMA SOURCE ION IMPLANTAT PROGRAM,835 ENGN RES BLDG,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53070.
z:row.Abstract: Specimens of Incoloy alloys 908 and 909 were implanted with nitrogen at temperatures of 100 and 400-degrees-C to a dose of 7 x 10(17) ions cm-2. Scanning Auger multiprobe (SAM) was used to determine the nitrogen concentration depth profiles, from which the retained doses were calculated. Microhardness measurements and pin-on-disk wear testing were performed to evaluate the surface property improvements. The thicknesses of implanted layers increased by about an order of magnitude when the temperature was elevated from 100 to 400-degrees-C. Higher surface hardness and wear resistance were also obtained in the higher temperature implantation. Transmission electron micrscopy images showed distinct microstructural changes and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy showed the presence of nitrides of titanium, chromium and niobium at the implanted surface.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Microstructural Study of Nitrogen-Implanted Ti-6al-4v Alloy
z:row.Keyword: ION-IMPLANTATION|METALS|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Atomic, Molecular & Chemical|Physics, Nuclear
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section B-Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: QIU, X, UNIV WISCONSIN,COLL ENGN,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A comprehensive study of the microstructural effects of nitrogen ion implantation on Ti-6Al-4V alloy has been carried out. The work was promoted by the fact that the corrosive wear resistance of Ti-6Al-4V alloy in an environment similar to that encountered in medical applications can be considerably improved by nitrogen ion implantation using the plasma source ion implantation technique. The alloy was implanted with 50 keV nitrogen ions to different doses ranging from 9 x 10(20) to 1 x 10(22) atoms/m2. Composition distribution within the implanted region was characterized by Auger electron spectroscopy. Microstructural studies were based on transmission electron microscopy. Better understanding of the wear/corrosion behavior is obtained from the study of the microstructures resulting from implantation and provides guidelines for further improvement of the wear/corrosion properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: HAN SH, 1990, NUCL INSTRUM METH B, V45, P701 HIGHAM PA, 1986, MATER RES SOC S P, V55, P253 HUTCHINGS R, 1983, WEAR, V92, P143 MATTHEWS FD, 1986, MATER RES SOC S P, V55, P243 MCHARGUE CJ, 1986, INT MET REV, V31, P49 OLIVER WC, 1984, MATER RES SOC S P, V27, P705 OLIVER WC, 1984, METALL TRANS A, V15, P2221 PEARSON WB, 1958, HDB LATTICE SPACINGS, P234 PERRY AJ, 1987, SURFACE ENG, V3, P154 QIU X, 1990, METALL TRANS A, V21, P1663 SARITAS S, 1987, MATER SCI ENG, V90, P297 SINGER IL, 1984, MATERIALS RES SOC S, V27, P585 SIOSHANSI P, 1986, MATER RES SOC S P, V55, P237 WANG Z, 1982, J NUCL MATER, V108, P331 WILLIAMS JM, 1984, MATERIALS RES SOC S, V27, P735 WILLIAMS JM, 1985, MATER SCI ENG, V69, P237 ZHANG JJ, 1986, MATER RES SOC S P, V55, P229; NR: 17; TC: 20; J9: NUCL INSTRUM METH PHYS RES B; PN: Part 2; PG: 6; GA: FZ030

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion-Beam Enhanced Deposition of Titanium-Nitride on Inconel 718
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SRIDHARAN, K, UNIV WISCONSIN,PLASMA SOURCE ION IMPLANTAT PROGRAM,835 ENGN RES BLDG,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A wear-resistant titanium-nitride film was successfully formed on the commercial superalloy INCONEL 718 with a plasma source ion-implantation unit operated in the ion-beam enhanced-deposition mode. The process was carried out at ambient temperature by alternately depositing titanium with a dc cathode sputter source followed by nitrogen implantation utilizing a plasma. Auger spectroscopy was used to determine the composition-depth profile of the surface film. Transmission electron microscopy indicated the film to be adherent and fine-grained. Tribological property improvements are attributed to both higher hardness and lower coefficient of friction of the titanium-nitride film.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of Spatial and Temporal Sheath Evolution for Spherical and Cylindrical Geometries in Plasma Source Ion-Implantation
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SHAMIM, M, UNIV WISCONSIN,PLASMA SOURCE ION IMPLANTAT GRP,1500 JOHNSON DR,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: A comparison of experimental measurements and numerical calculations of temporal and spatial sheath evolution is presented. Spherical targets of copper and stainless steel (radius = 2 cm) and a cylindrical target (radius = 0.95 cm, height = 18 cm) were immersed in an argon plasma with plasma densities of 2 x 10(8)-8 x 10(9) cm-3 and biased negatively (20-50 kV). A Langmuir probe was used to detect the propagating sheath edge. Experimental measurements of sheath edge position were in good agreement with those determined by numerical calculations.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comprehensive modeling of plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of 27th SAMPE International Technical Conference, 9-12 Oct. 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: 27th International SAMPE Technical Conference. Diversity into the Next Century Vol.27
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Albuquerque, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Center for Plasma Theory & Comput., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: As a critical step towards the development of a comprehensive model for plasma source ion implantation which will eventually include modules for the chamber and pulse modulator, plasma, implantation, diffusion, and materials physics such as hardness, the plasma and implantation modules have been linked. Presented are comparisons of the model to measured retained dose profiles for various ratios of applied bias rise time to total bias pulse time ratios which translate into various average energies of the impacting ion energy distribution for a paradigm case of nitrogen implantation into titanium or closely related alloys. Even though a best fit with a 20% drop in this average ion energy is obtained, a very low sensitivity of the above mentioned rise time ratio relative to the retained dose is observed. Precise modeling of the impacting ion energy distribution with many variables accounted for seems computationally inefficient for most cases. Simplified models for the plasma are suggested
z:row.User2: comprehensive modeling; plasma source ion implantation; pulse modulator; diffusion; hardness; implantation modules; retained dose profiles; applied bias rise time; total bias pulse time; average energies; impacting ion energy distribution; N implantation; average ion energy; Ti:N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Results from the AMANDA detector
z:row.TitleSecondary: Cracow Epiphany Conference on Astroparticle Physics, 8-11 Jan. 2004
z:row.Keyword: astronomical telescopes|Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|dark matter|Earth|neutrino detection|photomultipliers|Sun
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Cracow, Poland
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA Collaboration, Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array (AMANDA) is a high-energy neutrino telescope based at the geographic south pole. It is a lattice of photomultiplier tubes buried deep in the polar ice, which is used as interaction and detection medium. The primary goal of this detector is the observation of astronomical sources of high-energy neutrinos. This paper shows the latest results of the search for a diffuse flux of extraterrestrial νμs with energies between 1011 eV and 1018 eV, νμs emitted from point sources and νμs from dark matter annihilation in the Earth and the Sun
z:row.User2: AMANDA detector; Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array; high-energy neutrino telescope; geographic south pole; photomultiplier tube lattice; polar ice; astronomical source observation; extraterrestrial diffuse flux; point sources; dark matter annihilation; Earth; Sun

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sensitivity of the IceCube detector to astrophysical sources of high energy muon neutrinos
z:row.Keyword: active galaxies|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray muons|cosmic ray neutrinos|gamma-ray bursts|Monte Carlo methods|neutrino detection
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. of Phys., Mainz Univ., Germany
z:row.Abstract: We present results of a Monte Carlo study of the sensitivity of the planned IceCube detector to predicted fluxes of muon neutrinos at TeV to PeV energies. A complete simulation of the detector and data analysis is used to study the detector's capability to search for muon neutrinos from potential sources such as active galaxies and gamma-ray bursts (GRBs). We study the effective area and the angular resolution of the detector as a function of muon energy and angle of incidence. We present detailed calculations of the sensitivity of the detector to both diffuse and pointlike neutrino fluxes, including an assessment of the sensitivity to neutrinos detected in coincidence with GRB observations. After three years of data taking, IceCube is able to detect a point-source flux of Eν2×dNν/dEν=7×10-9 cm-2 s-1 GeV at a 5σ significance, or, in the absence of a signal, place a 90% c.l. limit at a level of Eν2×dNν/dEν=2×10-9 cm-2 s-1 GeV. A diffuse E-2 flux would be detectable at a minimum strength of Eν2×dNν/dEν=10-8 cm-2 s-1 sr-1 GeV. A GRB model following the formulation of Waxman and Bahcall would result in a 5σ effect after the observation of 200 bursts in coincidence with satellite observations of the gamma rays
z:row.User2: IceCube detector sensitivity analysis; astrophysical sources; high energy muon neutrinos; Monte Carlo methods; muon neutrino flux; data analysis; active galaxies; gamma-ray bursts; GRB; muon energy function; point source flux; diffuse neutrino flux; Bahcall formulation; Waxman formulation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search for supernova neutrino bursts with the AMANDA detector
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|galactic cosmic rays|neutrino detection|stellar radiation|supernovae
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. fur Phys., Mainz Univ., Germany
z:row.Abstract: The core collapse of a massive star in the Milky Way will produce a neutrino burst, intense enough to be detected by existing underground detectors. The AMANDA neutrino telescope located deep in the South Pole ice can detect MeV neutrinos by a collective rate increase in all photo-multipliers on top of dark noise. The main source of light comes from positrons produced in the CC reaction of anti-electron neutrinos on free protons ν¯e+p→e++n. This paper describes the first supernova search performed on the full sets of data taken during 1997 and 1998 (215 days of live time) with 302 of the detector's optical modules. No candidate events resulted from this search. The performance of the detector is calculated, yielding a 70% coverage of the Galaxy with one background fake per year with 90% efficiency for the detector configuration under study. An upper limit at the 90% c.l. on the rate of stellar collapses in the Milky Way is derived, yielding 4.3 events per year. A trigger algorithm is presented and its performance estimated. Possible improvements of the detector hardware are reviewed
z:row.User2: supernova neutrino bursts; AMANDA detector; core collapse; massive star; neutrino burst; underground detectors; neutrino telescope; MeV neutrinos; antineutrinoe + proton producing positron + neutron; AD 1997 to 1998; Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array; photo-multipliers; positrons; CC reaction; anti-electron neutrinos; free protons; supernova search

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of the cosmic ray composition at the knee with the SPASE-2/AMANDA-B10 detectors
z:row.Keyword: astronomical telescopes|Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray muons|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|cosmic ray showers|high-energy cosmic ray interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. of Phys., Mainz Univ., Germany
z:row.Abstract: The mass composition of high-energy cosmic rays at energies above 1015 eV can provide crucial information for the understanding of their origin. Air showers were measured simultaneously with the SPASE-2 air shower array and the AMANDA-B10 Cherenkov telescope at the South Pole. This combination has the advantage to sample almost all high-energy shower muons and is thus a new approach to the determination of the cosmic ray composition. The change in the cosmic ray mass composition was measured versus existing data from direct measurements at low energies. Our data show an increase of the mean log atomic mass ⟨ln A⟩ by about 0.8 between 500 TeV and 5 PeV. This trend of an increasing mass through the "knee" region is robust against a variety of systematic effects
z:row.User2: cosmic ray composition; high-energy cosmic rays; cosmic ray air showers; SPASE-2 air shower array; AMANDA-B10 Cherenkov telescope; South Pole; high-energy shower muons; cosmic ray mass composition; mean log atomic mass; knee region; cosmic ray origin

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search for point sources of high-energy neutrinos with AMANDA
z:row.Keyword: Cherenkov radiation|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|galactic cosmic rays|photomultipliers
z:row.Publisher: University of Chicago Press for American Astron. Soc
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lawrence Berkeley Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper describes the search for astronomical sources of high-energy neutrinos using the AMANDA-B10 detector, an array of 302 photomultiplier tubes used for the detection of Cerenkov light from upward-traveling neutrino-induced muons, buried deep in ice at the South Pole. The absolute pointing accuracy and angular resolution were studied by using coincident events between the AMANDA detector and two independent telescopes on the surface, the GASP air Cerenkov telescope and the SPASE extensive air shower array. Using data collected from 1997 April to October (130.1 days of live time), a general survey of the northern hemisphere revealed no statistically significant excess of events from any direction. The sensitivity for a flux of muon neutrinos is based on the effective detection area for through-going muons. Averaged over the northern sky, the effective detection area exceeds 10,000 m2 for Eμ≈10 TeV. Neutrinos generated in the atmosphere by cosmic-ray interactions were used to verify the predicted performance of the detector. For a source with a differential energy spectrum proportional to Eν-2 and declination larger than +40°, we obtain E2(dNν/dE)⩽10-6 GeV cm-2 s-1 for an energy threshold of 10 GeV
z:row.User2: AMANDA-B10 detector; high-energy neutrinos; photomultiplier tubes; Cerenkov light; upward-traveling neutrino-induced muons; absolute pointing accuracy; angular resolution; effective detection area; through-going muons; cosmic-ray interactions; differential energy spectrum

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neutral beam injection on the Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8), 14-16 May 1984
z:row.TitleTertiary: Conference Record of the 1984 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received) (Cat. No. 84CH1958-8)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: St. Louis, MO, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Until recently, neutral beam injection experiments on Phaedrus have been dominated by cold neutral gas streaming from the neutral beam sources. Charge exchange loss of hot plasma ions due to this cold gas source has limited beam induced diamagnetism and density buildup of the RF sustained target plasma to approximately 50% and 10% respectively. Major modifications of the neutral beam line vacuum system (in the form of additional and tighter baffles, and extension tubes which increase the distance between the sources and the plasma) were made in September, 1983. These modifications reduced the flow of neutral gas into the plug due to beamline gas by an order of magnitude, in agreement with Monte Carlo calculations. After the modifications were accomplished, it was discovered that the RF target plasma itself was characterized by a very high neutral pressure (edge pressure ~5×1011 cm-3). The origin of the higher neutral pressure problem, a proposed solution and the impact of the proposed solution on neutral beam injection is discussed
z:row.User2: Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment; neutral beam injection; hot plasma ions; cold gas source; RF target plasma; Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment; neutral beam injection; hot plasma ions; cold gas source; RF target plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear corrosion: Separation of the components of corrosion and wear
z:row.Keyword: Stainless Steel -- Corrosion|Stainless Steel - Wear|Corrosion - Components|Wear of Materials - Components|Stainless Steel - Cathodic Protection|Erosion
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An apparatus has been designed that permits separation of the wear and corrosion components of wear corrosion. A loaded ruby ball describes a circular track on a sheet specimen in a corrosion environment, with and without cathodic protection applied to the specimen to produce wear and wear corrosion, respectively. Profilometer traces of the tracks measure the metal removed in the two cases. Preliminary results on type 304 stainless steel demonstrate the validity of the technique.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Corrosion Rate; Depassivation; Repassivation; Wear Corrosion; Stainless Steel 304; Profilometer

z:row.TitlePrimary: Selected recent results from AMANDA
z:row.TitleSecondary: ICHEP 2000. Proceedings of the 30th International Physics, 27 July-2 Aug. 2000
z:row.TitleTertiary: ICHEP 2000. Proceedings of the 30th International Conference on High Energy Physics
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray apparatus|hypothetical particles|muon detection|neutron detection
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Osaka, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA Collaboration, Lawrence Livermore Nat. Lab., Berkeley, CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: We present a selection of results based on data taken in 1997 with the 302-PMT Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array-B10 ("AMANDA-B10") array. Atmospheric neutrinos created in the northern hemisphere are observed indirectly through their charged current interactions which produce relativistic, Cherenkov-light-emitting upgoing muons in the South Pole ice cap. The reconstructed angular distribution of these events is in good agreement with expectation and demonstrates the viability of this ice-based device as a neutrino telescope. Studies of nearly vertical upgoing muons limit the available parameter space for WIMP dark matter under the assumption that WIMPS are trapped in the earth's gravitational potential well and annihilate with one another near the earth's center
z:row.User2: AMANDA experimental results; 302-PMT; Antarctic muon detector array; Antarctic neutrino detector array; AMANDA-B10; atmospheric neutrinos; charged current interactions; relativistic Cherenkov-light-emitting muons; Cherenkov light; light diffuser ball; fiber optic cable; lightest supersymmetric particle; Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model; neutralino; South Pole ice cap; angular distribution; ice-based device; neutrino telescope; vertical upgoing muons; WIMP dark matter; earth gravitational potential well; weakly interacting massive particles

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neutral beam injection on the Phaedrus Tandem Mirror Experiment
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 23-25 May 1983
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1983 International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recent modifications of the neutral beam injection system on the Phaedrus Tandem Mirror Experiment have produced substantial improvements in the injection performance. The modifications consisted primarily of more tightly apertured baffles (smaller by a factor of two) in the beamline vacuum chamber to reduce the beamline cold gas neutral density incident on the plug. At the same time, the neutral beam energy was increased from 7 keV to 8.8 keV. The decreased neutral gas load leads to decreased charge exchange losses of trapped hot ions in the plug. With the smaller aperture baffles, the plug neutral gas density from the neutral beam sources decreases by a factor of two, the target diamagnetism immediately before injection increases by almost a factor of three, and the increase in plug diamagnetism due to the beam injection doubles. The most significant improvement is the increase in plug line density buildup (~20% increase) on Phaedrus
z:row.User2: Phaedrus Tandem Mirror Experiment; neutral beam injection; beamline vacuum chamber; charge exchange losses; trapped hot ions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion implantation has been shown to be a very effective process for improving the corrosion and wear resistance of materials. The authors are developing a technique for ion implantation with a plasma source that offers considerable advantages relative to existing techniques. The authors' technique allows the ion implantation to be performed directly within the ion source at higher currents without ion beam extraction and transport. The potential benefits include greatly increased production rates (factors of 10-1000) and the ability to implant non-plant targets without rastering or shadowing. Our technique eliminates the ion extractor grid set, beam raster equipment, drift space and target manipulator equipment. The target to be implanted is placed directly within the plasma source and is biased to a large negative potential so that plasma ions gain energy as they accelerate through the potential drop across the sheath that forms at the plasma boundary
z:row.User2: ion implantation; plasma source

z:row.TitlePrimary: Trapping and pumping of ions in the thermal barrier region of Phaedrus-B, a tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6), 19-21 May 1986
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1986 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.86CH2317-6)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Saskatoon, Sask., Canada
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: RF trapping by propagating slow waves generated by the plug ICRH antenna in the thermal barrier region of Phaedrus-B is investigated. Classical processes such as neutral collisions and Coulomb scattering are also studied. Results of these studies as well as initial results of single frequency RF drift pumping studies are reported
z:row.User2: ion trapping; ion pumping; RF trapping; Coulomb scattering; RF drift pumping; thermal barrier region; Phaedrus-B; slow waves; neutral collisions; single frequency RF drift pumping

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sheath physics and materials science results from recent plasma source ion implantation experiments
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3), 1-3 June 1987
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1987 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.87CH2451-3)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a surface modification technique which has been optimized for ion-beam processing of materials. PSII departs radically from conventional implantation by circumventing the line-of-sight restriction inherent in conventional ion implantation. The authors have used PSII to implant cutting tools and dies and have demonstrated substantial improvements in lifetime. Recent results on plasma physics scaling laws, microstructural, mechanical, and tribological properties of PSII-implanted materials are presented
z:row.User2: microstructural properties; mechanical properties; materials science; plasma source ion implantation experiments; PSII; surface modification; ion-beam processing; scaling laws; tribological properties

z:row.TitlePrimary: Chromium plating pollution source reduction by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: Auger effect|chromium|electron spectroscopy|ion implantation|nitrogen|plasma deposition|scanning electron microscopy|spectrochemical analysis|surface hardening
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There is growing concern over the environmental toxicity and workers' health issues due to the chemical baths and rinse water used in the hard chromium plating process. In this regard the significant hardening response of chromium to nitrogen ion implantation can be environmentally beneficial from the standpoint of decreasing the thickness and the frequency of application of chromium plating. In this paper the results of a study of nitrogen ion implantation of chrome plated test flats using the non-line-of-sight Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII) process, are discussed. Surface characterization was performed using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Auger Electron Spectroscopy (AES), and Electron Spectroscopy for Chemical Analysis (ESCA). The surface properties were evaluated using a microhardness tester, a pin-on-disk wear tester, and a corrosion measurement system. Industrial field testing of nitrogen PSII treated chromium plated parts showed an improvement by a factor of two compared to the unimplanted case
z:row.User2: Cr plating pollution source reduction; plasma source ion implantation; environmental toxicity; workers' health issues; chemical baths; rinse water; hard chromium plating process; N ion implantation; chrome plated test flats; nonline-of-sight process; surface characterization; scanning electron microscopy; Auger electron spectroscopy; electron spectroscopy for chemical analysis; microhardness tester; pin-on-disk wear tester; corrosion measurement system; field testing; plated parts; Cr; N2

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation: history, successes, failures, challenges, and future prospects
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: ion implantation|ion sources|plasma applications|plasma production|plasma sheaths|semiconductor technology
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII) represents a radical departure from conventional ion implantation technology. PSII circumvents the line of sight restriction inherent in conventional ion implantation. In PSII, targets to be implanted are placed directly in a plasma source and then pulse-biased to a high negative potential. A plasma ion matrix sheath forms around the target and ions bombard the entire target compared with conventional ion implantation, PSII minimizes the problems of shadowing and excessive sputtering of the target material, which can severely limit the retained dose of the implanted ion species. Uniformity can be achieved in a batch processing mode. The author presents: a historical overview of the development of PSII, a brief review of PSII physics and technology, a summary of world-wide PSII activities, a discussion of laboratory and industrial field test results with PSII, recent developments leading to scale-up and commercialization of PSII, recent extensions of PSII technology to semiconductor processing, and an assessment of future prospects for commercial development of PSII
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; future prospects; history; successes; failures; challenges; ion implantation technology; targets; plasma source; pulse-biased targets; negative potential; plasma ion matrix sheath; excessive sputtering; shadowing; implanted ion species; batch processing mode; historical overview; review; test results; semiconductor processing

z:row.TitlePrimary: Deposition of diamond-like carbon (DLC) films using hydrocarbon plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: Auger effect|carbon|electron energy loss spectra|electron spectra|hardness|hardness testing|hydrogen|ion implantation|plasma deposition|Raman spectra|Rutherford backscattering|thin films|transmission electron microscopy|tribology
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. The structure-property relationships of two differently processed hydrogenated amorphous carbon thin films (a-C:H) and their application as protective overcoats for thin film magnetic media have been studied. The films were deposited by a reactive sputtering system and the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) techniques. Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RES) and forward recoil energy spectrometry (FRES) results showed all film compositions to be in the following carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atomic percent ranges 402 and sp3 bonded carbon. Scanning Auger microscopy (SAM) revealed an indication of carbide formation in the biased film. Optical, hardness, and adhesion qualities of the films compared well with those reported in literature. Pin-on-disk and thin film head-on-disk tests were performed to study the tribological characteristics of the films. For the sputtered films a correlation was found between Raman spectroscopy results and carbon durability. A methodology for classification of a-C:H films by their composition, structure as well as their optical and mechanical properties will be presented

Atmospheric neutrinos created in the northern hemisphere are observed indirectly through their charged current interactions which produce relativistic, Cherenkov-light-emitting upgoing muons in the South Pole ice cap. z:row.TitlePrimary: Comprehensive modeling of plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1995 27th International SAMPE Technical Conference, Oct 9-12 1995
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Albuquerque, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: As a critical step towards the development of a comprehensive model for plasma source ion implantation which will eventually include modules for the chamber and pulse modulator, plasma, implantation, diffusion, and materials physics such as hardness, the plasma and implantation modules have been linked. Presented are comparisons of the model to measured retained dose profiles for various ratios of applied bias rise time to total bias pulse time ratios which translate into various average energies of the impacting ion energy distribution for a paradigm case of nitrogen implantation into titanium or closely related alloys. Even though a best fit with a 20% drop in this average ion energy is obtained, a very low sensitivity of the above mentioned rise time ratio relative to the retained dose is observed. Precise modeling of the impacting ion energy distribution with many variables accounted for seems computationally inefficient for most cases. Simplified models for the plasma are suggested.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma source ion implantation; Pulse modulator; Materials physics; Applied bias rise time; Total bias pulse time; Nitrogen implantation; Ion energy distribution

z:row.TitlePrimary: New low dielectric constant, high Tg, printed circuitry substrates
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of IPC Printed Circuits EXPO '98, 26-30 April 1998
z:row.TitleTertiary: IPC Printed Circuits Expo '98. Proceedings of the Technical Conference
z:row.Keyword: circuit reliability|dielectric losses|dielectric thin films|glass fibre reinforced plastics|glass transition|laminates|microwave materials|packaging|permittivity|printed circuit manufacture
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Long Beach, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AlliedSignal Laminate Syst. Inc., LaCrosse, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: AlliedSignal has developed a new family of fiber glass reinforced substrates (FR408) using a specially formulated epoxy resin to achieve a robust combination of performance and processing characteristics. These substrates are low dielectric constant (Dk or ϵ), low loss (Df or tan δ) laminates with high glass transition temperatures (Tg) which allow standard FR4 PCB fabrication processes. Their electrical properties are relatively insensitive to frequency, making these materials suitable for demanding communications, computing, and instrument applications. This paper discusses these new technologies, presenting results of PCB fabrication techniques for these materials as well as the benefits to the end users. Other products which address these needs have proven to be more difficult to process than standard FR4 materials. Comparisons of fabrication techniques of this product to FR4 processes are made. End user requirements such as dielectric performance in the GHz frequency range are compared to industry standard products
z:row.User2: dielectric constant; printed circuit substrates; electronics packaging; electronic applications; wireless communications infrastructure; satellite communications; desktop workstations; materials electrical performance criteria; materials cost criteria; polymer technology; laminate process technology; fiber glass reinforced substrates; epoxy resin; dielectric loss; laminates; glass transition temperature; standard FR4 PCB fabrication processes; frequency-insensitive electrical properties; instrument applications; communications applications; computing applications; PCB fabrication techniques; dielectric performance; industry standard products; fabrication techniques

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dependence of ion-matrix dose on density for planar, cylindrical, and spherical electrodes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion-matrix dose dependence calculations for plasma source ion implantation in planar, cylindrical, and spherical geometries are presented. It is demonstrated that in the high plasma density limit (in relation to the applied electrode potential and electrode size), the spherical and cylindrical cases approach the planar case. However, in the low relative density limit, the density dependencies diverge with the dependence vanishing for the spherical case, remaining unchanged for the planar case, and with the cylindrical case lying between the previous two

z:row.Abstract: Analytic expressions have been obtained for the potential profile and sheath thickness of the transient ion-matrix sheath which forms when a large negative step potential is applied to planar, cylindrical, and spherical electrodes immersed in a plasma
z:row.User2: potential profiles; ion-matrix sheaths; cylindrical; spherical electrodes; sheath thickness; large negative step potential

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of electron emission due to energetic ion bombardment in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An experimental procedure has been developed to measure electron emission due to energetic ion bombardment during plasma source ion implantation. Spherical targets (radius=2 cm) of copper, stainless steel, graphite, titanium alloy (Ti-6Al-4V) and aluminum alloy (6061) were biased negatively to 20, 30, and 40 kV in argon and nitrogen plasmas. A Langmuir probe was used to detect the propagating sheath edge and a Rogowski transformer was used to measure the current to the target. The measurements of electron emission coefficients compare well with those measured under similar conditions [B. Szapiro and J.J. Rocca, J. Appl. Phys. 65, 3713 (1989)]
z:row.User2: electron emission; energetic ion bombardment; plasma source ion implantation; stainless steel; graphite; Langmuir probe; propagating sheath edge; Rogowski transformer; Cu; FeCrC; C; TiAlV

z:row.TitlePrimary: EXPERIMENTAL MEASUREMENT OF INCREASED NEUTRAL BEAM DIVERGENCE DUE TO A TRANSVERSE MAGNETIC FIELD
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The deflection and increased divergence of a neutral beam due to a magnetic field perpendicular to the gas-cell neutralizer has been measured. The hydrogen neutral beam energy was 5. 0 keV. The observed neutral beam deflection and divergence agreed well with results obtained from solutions of a coupled set of kinetic equations for the transverse velocity distribution functions for energetic ions and neutrals in the neutralizer volume.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Model of plasma source ion implantation in planar, cylindrical, and spherical geometries
z:row.Keyword: ion implantation|ion sources|plasma applications|plasma sheaths|space-charge-limited conduction
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Plasma Source Ion Implantation Group, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A model has been developed that describes the propagation of the transient sheath during a pulse of high negative voltage applied to a conductor immersed in a plasma such as that present in plasma source ion implantation. This model assumes that the transient sheath obeys the Child-Langmuir law for space-charge-limited emission at each instant during the propagation of the sheath. Expressions are obtained for the sheath-edge position as a function of time. The model predicts the final sheath extent and average ion current to the target during each pulse for planar, cylindrical, and spherical geometries
z:row.User2: voltage pulse; cylindrical geometries; planar geometries; plasma source ion implantation; spherical geometries; transient sheath; conductor; Child-Langmuir law; space-charge-limited emission

z:row.TitlePrimary: DISCHARGE AND ION EXTRACTION PROPERTIES OF A BEAM-PLASMA ION SOURCE
z:row.Keyword: ION SOURCES -- Measurements|ELECTRON BEAMS - Velocity Measurement|PLASMAS - Production|ELECTROMAGNETISM|ELECTRON GUNS - Applications|ELECTRIC DISCHARGES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The discharge and ion extraction properties of a beam-plasma ion source have been studied experimentally. The extractable ion current is maximized when the discharge column length is chosen to be an optimum length. The peak extracted ion current can exceed the Child-Langmuir current as much as an order of magnitude.
