z:row.User2: ION EXTRACTION; BEAM-PLASMA ION SOURCES; MAGNETICALLY FOCUSED ELECTRON BEAM; NEUTRAL GASES; ELECTRON IMPACT IONIZATION

z:row.TitlePrimary: ENHANCED NEUTRAL-BEAM DIVERGENCE DUE TO IMPERFECT MAGNETIC SHIELDING
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: A previous calculation of neutral-beam divergence due to imperfect magnetic shielding of the gas-cell neutralizer is expanded to include the case in which the intrinsic magnetic-field-free divergence of the beam is finite.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion emission from beam-plasma ion sources
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The author shows that maximum ion current is obtained from beam plasma ion sources when the initial growth rate of the beam-driven waves is maximised and when the plasma density is chosen to optimize the transfer of wave energy to plasma electron thermal energy. The peak ion current is calculated using a model based on nonlinear theory of beam-plasma interaction and reasonable agreement is found with experiment
z:row.User2: maximum ion current; beam plasma ion sources; plasma density; wave energy; thermal energy; nonlinear theory; ion emission

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neutral-beam divergence due to imperfect magnetic shielding
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The divergence of a neutral beam due to imperfect magnetic shielding of the gas-cell neutralizer is considered. Coupled kinetic equations for the ion and neutral velocity distribution functions are solved. The deflection and divergence of the neutral beam are obtained from moments of the neutral distribution function
z:row.User2: imperfect magnetic shielding; velocity distribution functions; neutral beam divergence; gas cell neutraliser; coupled kinetic equations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion-implantation technique for surface modification of materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion-implantation (PSII) is a new ion-implantation technique which has been optimized for surface modification of materials such as metals, plastics, and ceramics. PSII departs radically from conventional implantation technology by circumventing the line-of-sight restriction inherent in conventional ion implantation. In PSII, targets to be implanted are placed directly in a plasma source and then pulse biased to a high negative potential. A plasma sheath forms around the target and ions bombard the entire target simultaneously. Preliminary experiments have demonstrated that PSII: (1) efficiently implants ions to concentrations and depths required for surface modification, (2) produces material with improved microhardness and wear properties, and (3) dramatically improves the life of manufacturing tools in actual industrial applications. For example, the tool life of M-2 pierce punches used to produce holes in mild steel plate has been increased by a factor of 80
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; surface modification; plasma sheath; microhardness; wear; life; manufacturing tools

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of ion species ratio in the plasma source ion implantation process
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|Auger effect|ion implantation|nitrogen|physics computing|plasma applications|plasma diagnostics|plasma sheaths|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion species and their ratios in nitrogen, oxygen, and argon plasmas in the plasma source ion implantation process have been determined with a simple and low-cost measurement system. The measured ion species ratio in the nitrogen plasma was used as an input parameter for the computer simulation code transport and mixing from ion irradiation to predict the atomic composition-depth profile. Comparison between the code results and data derived from Auger analysis for a nitrogen-implanted Ti-6Al-4V alloy showed good agreement. The design, performance, and possible future improvements regarding the resolution of this measurement system is discussed
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; ion species ratio; computer simulation code transport; atomic composition-depth profile; Auger analysis; N2; O2; Ar; TiAlV

z:row.TitlePrimary: Optimum discharge parameters for beam-plasma ion sources
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A recently published model (see ibid., vol.47, p.4859 (1976)) for the ion emission from beam-plasma ion sources has been reexamined and extended to obtain an expression which formulates the optimum discharge parameter condition. The predictions of the expression derived have then been compared with experimental data
z:row.User2: optimum discharge parameters; beam plasma ion sources

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of spatial and temporal sheath evolution for spherical and cylindrical geometries in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A comparison of experimental measurements and numerical calculations of temporal and spatial sheath evolution is presented. Spherical targets of copper and stainless steel (radius=2 cm) and a cylindrical target (radius=0.95 cm, height=18 cm) were immersed in an argon plasma with plasma densities of 2×108-8×109 cm-3 and biased negatively (20-50 kV). A Langmuir probe was used to detect the propagating sheath edge. Experimental measurements of sheath edge position were in good agreement with those determined by numerical calculations
z:row.User2: spherical target; Ar plasma; temporal sheath evolution; plasma source ion implantation; spatial sheath evolution; stainless steel; cylindrical target; plasma densities; Langmuir probe; propagating sheath edge; numerical calculations; Cu

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation dose uniformity of a 2×2 array of spherical targets
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|ion implantation|Rutherford backscattering|secondary ion mass spectra|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors have employed Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy and secondary ion mass spectrometry to characterize the ion implantation dose uniformity which can be achieved with plasma source ion implantation (PSII), a non-line-of-sight technique for ion implantation of nonplanar targets in nonsemiconductor applications. In order to characterize the dose uniformity achievable with PSII, four spherical Ti-6Al-4V targets were PSII implanted simultaneously as a 2×2 square array in a nitrogen plasma with density 3×109 cm-3 at an energy of 50 keV to a nominal dose of 3×1017 atoms/cm2. The measured root-mean-square variation of both the retained dose and the mean range was found to be less than 15%, which is well within the acceptable tolerance range for nonsemiconductor applications of ion implantation. The results demonstrate that PSII can achieve acceptable dose uniformity on nonplanar targets without target manipulation, and that such uniformity can be achieved in a batch processing mode
z:row.User2: ion implantation dose uniformity; 2×2 array; spherical targets; Rutherford backscattering; secondary ion mass spectrometry; plasma source; batch processing; Ti-Al-V

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison between conventional and plasma source ion-implanted femoral knee components
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen ion implantation of Ti-6Al-4V knee joint femoral components was carried out by both plasma source ion implantation (PSII), a non-line of sight technique, and conventional beamline implantation. Implantation using the PSII process was performed on a flat sample as well as a 2×2 square array of components to demonstrate batch processing capability. The retained dose of the flat sample and at different locations on the implanted components was measured by a scanning Auger microprobe (SAM). The variation in dose of the PSII treated component was found to be within the SAM error, while the dose at one location on the beamline implanted component was found to be significantly low. For the beamline case, the SAM results show good agreement with the PC profile computer simulation, which includes the angular dependence of sputtering
z:row.User2: ion-implanted femoral knee components; plasma source ion implantation; beamline implantation; batch processing capability; retained dose; scanning Auger microprobe; Ti90Al6V4:N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Distribution of incident ions and retained dose analysis for a wedge-shaped target in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A wedge-shaped target was implanted with nitrogen ions using the plasma source ion implantation process, in order to understand the effects of the target edges on the energy and fluence distribution of incident ions. Experimental measurements and analysis of retained dose on silicon samples affixed on the surface of the target, showed results consistent with those predicted by theoretical models. Higher retained dose and greater implantation depths were observed in the vicinity of the edge contained by the normal angle as compared to the edges contained by the acute angles. The target face with smaller area accumulated, on the average, higher dose compared to the face with the larger area
z:row.User2: retained dose analysis; wedge-shaped target; plasma source ion implantation; incident ions distribution; fluence distribution; energy distribution; implantation depths; normal angle; acute angle

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structure and properties of amorphous diamond-like carbon films produced by ion beam assisted plasma deposition
z:row.Keyword: Amorphous films|Microstructure|Tribology|Carbon|Ion beams|Deposition|Ion implantation|Raman scattering|Transmission electron microscopy|Diffraction|Plasma sources|Hydrocarbons
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
z:row.Publisher: ASM International, Materials Park, OH, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The microstructure and tribological properties of carbon film produced by ion beam assisted plasma deposition in a plasma source ion implantation (PSII) chamber with energies varied from 0 to 30 keV are examined. The process is illustrated schematically, and Raman spectra as well as TEM images and corresponding diffraction patterns of carbon films are shown.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Tribological properties; Ion beam assisted plasma deposition; Carbon film; Plasma source ion implantation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Use of nitrogen-implanted chromium overcoat for improving the durability of thin-film magnetic media
z:row.Keyword: Magnetic disk storage|Chromium|Coatings|Thin films|Nitrogen|Computer hardware|Plasmas|Ion implantation|Durability
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A feasibility study of the use of nitrogen-implanted chromium as a protective overcoat for thin-film magnetic media was undertaken. Computer hard disks that were pre-sputtered with chromium were implanted with nitrogen using the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) process to produce a chromium nitride containing layer approximately 25 nm thick. Elemental concentration-depth profiles were determined with a scanning Auger microprobe. The presence of chromium nitride in the implanted layer was verified by examination of the broad scan of the Auger spectra. The durability of the PSII-treated hard disks relative to those with a standard carbon overcoat has been characterized with nanohardness, pin-on-disk and thin-film head-on-disk wear tests. A vibrating sample magnetometer was used to evaluate the magnetic properties or the disks. It has been demonstrated that PSII processing has the potential to improve the durability of hard disks without any significant reduction in the magnetic properties.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Chromium overcoats; Nitrogen implantation; Thin film magnetic media

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear modeling for nitrogen-implanted Ti-6Al-4V
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The wear resistance of ion-implanted Ti-6Al-4V test specimens was measured with a pin-on-disk wear tester. The samples were implanted by the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) technique using 50 keV nitrogen ions. Empirical models for both the wear depth and the wear lifetime were developed and the results were compared to unimplanted samples. PSII was shown to improve the wear resistance by factors of 20 to 55, depending on the applied load
z:row.User2: ion implantation; wear resistance; pin-on-disk wear tester; plasma source ion implantation; 50 keV; Ti-Al-V; Ti-Al-V-N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Methane plasma source ion implantation (PSII) for improvement of tribological and corrosion properties
z:row.Keyword: Ion implantation|Carbon|Stainless steel|Tribology|Corrosion|Plasma sources|Wear of materials|Structure (composition)|Titanium alloys
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Carbon was implanted into type 304 stainless-steel and Ti-6Al-4V at a target bias of -30 keV using methane Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII). An evaluation was carried out to determine the effects of high voltage repetition rates on implantation structure, wear and corrosion properties. The carbon depth profile, the structure as well as the resultant properties of 304 stainless-steel after implantation were found to be sensitive to the implantation repetition rate. Furthermore, there was no dependence of either the structure or the extent of improvement of the properties of the Ti-6Al-4V alloy on the implantation repetition rate.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma source ion implantation; Line of sight restrictions; High voltage repetition rates; Implantation structure; Corrosion properties; Tribological properties; Carbon depth profile

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fretting wear study of a nitrogen implanted titanium alloy
z:row.Keyword: Titanium alloys|Wear of materials|Fretting corrosion|Implants (surgical)|Nitrogen|Ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylenes|Friction|Frequencies|Oscillations|Scanning electron microscopy|Wear resistance|Optical microscopy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Fretting wear, which results from oscillatory micromotion between two solids surfaces in contact, is one mechanism by which wear debris can be produced in orthopedic implants. In this paper, the fretting wear used is designed to model an oscillating couple at frequencies from 15 to 115 Hz, with a slip amplitude of up to 600 μm. In the study, the Ti-6Al-4V tests flats are metallographically polished with 1 μm diamond paste then implanted with nitrogen using PSII, at 50 keV to a dose of 3 × 1017 atoms cm-2, at ambient temperature. For fretting wear studies of a Ti-6Al-4V/Ti-6Al-4V wear couple, the flat circular face of 3 mm diameter Ti-6Al-4V rod is fretted against untreated and PSII treated Ti-6Al-4V test flats. Results are presented in detail.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ductile tearing; Wear scar; Surface chemistry

z:row.TitlePrimary: Gas flow measurements of a novel geometry for neutral beam neutralizers
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The conductance and line density of a novel geometry (pumped geometry) for neutral beam neutralizers were measured and compared with a conventional (passive) neutralizer geometry in the transition flow regime. A passive neutralizer geometry is merely a duct attached to the ion source. For the pumped geometry, the top and bottom surfaces of the duct are replaced by a venetian blind geometry which opens into ballast vacuum pumping volumes. A one-half scale model with pumped neutralizer geometry was built and compared with a passive neutralizer geometry of comparable dimensions. A gas source was maintained at fixed pressure and the conductance and line density of the two geometries were measured. These measurements were repeated for several values of gas source pressure, covering the range of pressures typically used in neutral beam ion sources. With the vanes on the pumped neutralizer geometry opened to 55 deg and the gas source pressure `low', i.e. in the range of pressures typical for `bucket-type' magnetic field ion sources, the amount of gas flowing from the exit to the pumped geometry was about 3 times less than the amount flowing from the passive geometry. As the source gas pressure was increased, the ratio of gas flow from the exit of the passive geometry to that of the pumped geometry increased also. At gas source pressures typical of magnetic field free ion sources, up to 5 times less gas flowed from the pumped geometry. On the other hand, the neutral gas line density of the pumped geometry was only 1.6 times less than that of the passive geometry, independent of the source gas pressure
z:row.User2: gas flow measurements; neutral beam neutralizers; conductance; line density; pumped geometry; transition flow regime; passive neutralizer geometry

z:row.TitlePrimary: Neutral density effects in the end cells of the Phaedrus tandem mirror
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Cold neutral gas density has important consequences for the energy and particle balances of the hot ion plasma in the end cells of tandem mirrors. Charge exchange loss from cold gas penetration into this plasma detracts from the pressure in the end cells needed for magnetohydrodynamic stability of the mirror. Unfortunately, cold gas can be a by-product of neutral beam injection and of fueling. This report describes measurements of neutral pressure in the RF heated tandem mirror Phaedrus. The emphasis is on the dynamics of gas flow into the end cells, the effects of cold gas on the plasma, and on wall reflux for different wall conditions. The effects of neutral beams and neutral beam generated wall reflux was also studied. A numerical gas flow code is used to model the effects of plasma pumping, charge exchange, and wall reflux on end cell plasma parameters. The titanium sticking coefficient for hydrogen gas was determined to be 0.08±0.08. Wall reflux coefficients in the end cell were determined to be 1.4±0.2 without titanium gettering and 0.75±0.25 with gettering
z:row.User2: end cells; Phaedrus tandem mirror; neutral gas density; hot ion plasma; RF heated; dynamics; cold gas; wall reflux; neutral beams; numerical gas flow code; plasma pumping; charge exchange; sticking coefficient; gettering; Ti; H2

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion beam assisted coating and surface modification with plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a non-line-of-sight technique which is being developed as an alternative to beamline accelerator technology for ion implantation. The initial development phase of PSII concentrated on implantation of ion species which are gaseous at room temperature (primarily nitrogen ions) and employed a cylindrical vacuum chamber 16 in. high and 14 in. in diameter. A second generation PSII system is being constructed to extend the PSII process to ion beam mixing and ion beam assisted coating modes of operation. The new, larger system (with dimensions 36×36×36 in.) will feature multiple-array sources for sputter deposition concurrent with ion bombardment
z:row.User2: nonline-of-sight technique; surface modification; plasma source ion implantation; ion beam mixing; ion beam assisted coating modes; multiple-array sources; sputter deposition

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structure and property correlation of plasma source ion implanted layers in Monel K-500 alloy
z:row.TitleSecondary: 36th National Symposium of the American Vacuum Society, 23-27 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|Auger effect|copper alloys|friction|hardness|ion implantation|nickel alloys|titanium alloys|transmission electron microscope examination of materials|wear resistant coatings
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Boston, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Coll. of Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Monel series of nickel base alloys (Ni-Cu type) are attractive for components like bearings and shafts operating in high magnetizing environments because of their nonmagnetic characteristic coupled with superior corrosion and oxidation resistance at extreme service temperatures. Unfortunately, the current bearing technology is based on the use of two classes of materials, 5000 series alloy steels and 400 series stainless steels, both of which are magnetic. Thus, the successful operation of a magnetic device requires a new class of bearing materials. Some of the nonferrous materials, such as Monels, have not demonstrated superior wear characteristics as bearing materials. Plasma source ion implantation (PSII), a non-line-of-sight technology for implanting preferably gaseous species, is a new and innovative approach to surface modification of materials. Recently, it was reported that nitrogen implantation of the solution annealed and age hardened Monel K-500 alloy by the PSII process resulted in a significant improvement in the adhesive/sliding wear resistance with no perceptible increase in the low-load microhardness. The Auger analysis of the implanted layer showed a peak nitrogen concentration of about 10 at.%. The principal objective of the present investigation was to understand the unusual nature of the implanted layer and to arrive at plausible mechanisms for wear improvement in this material. Monel K-500 alloy samples were nitrogen implanted by the PSII process. The modified layers were investigated by nanohardness testing, transmission electron microscopy, and pin on disk wear and friction measurements. The results of these studies show: 20%-60% increase in hardness; significant reduction in the friction coefficient under unlubricated condition; and a more complex microstructure, due to nitrogen implantation
z:row.User2: corrosion resistance; property correlation; plasma source ion implanted layers; Monel K-500 alloy; nonmagnetic; oxidation resistance; surface modification; age hardened; Auger analysis; wear improvement; nanohardness testing; transmission electron microscopy; friction measurements; Ni-Cu-Al-Ti

z:row.TitlePrimary: Development of an energetic ion assisted mixing and deposition process for TiNx and diamondlike carbon films, using a co-axial geometry in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. A, Vac. Surf. Films (USA)
z:row.Keyword: carbon|ion beam mixing|ion implantation|thin films|titanium compounds|vapour deposition
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology A (Vacuum, Surfaces, and Films)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a relatively simple technique for the ion implantation/deposition of materials. In PSII a substrate is immersed in a plasma, and high negative voltage pulses are applied to accelerate ions into the substrate resulting in modification of the properties of the material in the near surface region. A technique was developed to produce uniform diamondlike carbon coatings and TiNx films inside and outside a hollow cylinder (substrate). A description of apparatus, experimental methods for this type of deposition process, and preliminary results are presented in this article
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; high negative voltage pulses; near surface region; diamondlike carbon coatings; TiNx films; hollow cylinder; deposition process; energetic ion assisted mixing; Co-axial geometry; C; TiN

z:row.TitlePrimary: High dose rate effects in silicon by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fourth International Plasma-Based Ion Implantation Workshop, 2-4 June 1998
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. B, Microelectron. Nanometer Struct. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: amorphisation|electron diffraction|elemental semiconductors|ion implantation|plasma materials processing|Rutherford backscattering|silicon|transmission electron microscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B (Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Dearborn, MI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An investigation of high dose rate effects in silicon subsurface morphology has been performed. The unique capability of plasma source ion implantation to operate in the high current/low energy regime, where the near-surface structure can be effectively controlled, has been studied. At an ion energy of ~40 keV and an estimated dose of 1×1015 cm-2 Ar ions were implanted at various instantaneous dose rates (0.75-8.3 mA/cm2) and two different pulse widths (25-50 μs) into 2 in. diam silicon wafers at a constant repetition rate of 10 Hz. The irradiation damage to the wafers' structures was characterized by Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). A visual observation indicated amorphization of the silicon at 0.75 mA/cm2, but not at 8.3 mA/cm2. The transition from the crystalline-to-amorphous phase was confirmed by TEM electron diffraction studies. RBS data, however, indicated there was a large discrepancy in the total dose retained between the high dose rate (8.3 mA/cm2) and the low dose rate (0.75 mA/cm2). Two simulation methods for the substrate temperature profile have been compared to predict the profile. A comparison of the fraction of irradiation damage from the RBS data indicated that the substrate heating effects are more dominant then the dose rate effects. Improved methods of cooling the wafer are presently being investigated
z:row.User2: dose rate; plasma source ion implantation; silicon subsurface morphology; Rutherford backscattering spectrometry; irradiation damage; transmission electron microscopy; amorphization; crystalline-amorphous phase transition; simulation; substrate temperature profile; wafer cooling; electron diffraction; Si

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dose analysis of nitrogen plasma source ion implantation treatment of titanium alloys
z:row.TitleSecondary: First International Workshop on Plasma-Based Ion Implantation, 4-6 Aug. 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. B, Microelectron. Nanometer Struct. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: Auger effect|ion implantation|plasma applications|secondary electron emission|surface hardening|titanium alloys
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B (Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Plasma Source Ion Implantation Group, Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Dose analysis of plasma source ion implantation (PSII) treatment involves two issues: calculation of the delivered dose and measurement of the retained dose. This article discusses the delivered dose calculation method and the determination of constants used in this calculation, such as the secondary electron emission coefficient and average number of atoms per ion being implanted. Both can be measured experimentally at the University of Wisconsin PSII group. The retained dose is usually studied by Auger electron spectroscopy (AES). For nitrogen PSII treated titanium alloys, like all titanium nitrogen compounds, the chemical analysis by AES is complicated by two factors: (1) the Auger electron emission from nitrogen occurs at an energy that completely overlaps a transition from titanium; and (2) titanium oxide has a strong influence on the titanium transitions. In this study, a new technique that takes into account the influence of titanium oxide and solves the overlap problem has been developed to convert AES data to a concentration depth profile. A comparison of the concentration profile for nitrogen as observed in the AES data and calculated by the TAMIX code (computer simulation) shows good agreement
z:row.User2: dose analysis; nitrogen plasma source ion implantation treatment; titanium alloys; delivered dose; secondary electron emission coefficient; Auger electron spectroscopy; chemical analysis; titanium oxide; overlap problem; concentration depth profile; TAMIX code; computer simulation; titanium nitrogen compounds; retained dose; N2; TiO; TiN

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structural characterization of plasma-doped silicon by high resolution X-ray diffraction
z:row.TitleSecondary: First International Workshop on Plasma-Based Ion Implantation, 4-6 Aug. 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. B, Microelectron. Nanometer Struct. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: annealing|boron|elemental semiconductors|ion implantation|plasma applications|rapid thermal processing|silicon|X-ray diffraction examination of materials
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B (Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High resolution X-ray diffraction methods have been used to characterize boron-doped silicon fabricated using low energy plasma source ion implantation (PSII). Double-crystal rocking curves recorded using the asymmetric (113) reflection show increasing intensity in the low-angle tail as the ion dose was increased from 1.1×1015 to 4.4×1015 cm-2. Scans of the diffuse intensity around the 113 point in reciprocal space using triple crystal diffraction showed no significant differences in the magnitude of diffuse kinematic scattering from an unimplanted control sample and the plasma doped silicon; in all cases, negligible diffuse scattering was observed. This suggests that the doping by PSII is accompanied by negligible amount of crystallographic damage. Postimplant rapid thermal annealing was found to cause no change in the level of diffuse scattering; however, the asymmetry in the double-crystal rocking curves switched to the high-angle side. Dynamic simulation of the rocking curves has been used to estimate the strain distribution in the as-implanted and annealed samples
z:row.User2: high resolution X-ray diffraction; plasma-doped silicon; low energy plasma source ion implantation; boron-doped silicon; double-crystal rocking curves; structure; triple crystal diffraction; diffuse kinematic scattering; crystallographic damage; rapid thermal annealing; dynamic simulation; strain distribution; Si:B

z:row.TitlePrimary: Overview of plasma source ion implantation research at University of Wisconsin-Madison
z:row.TitleSecondary: First International Workshop on Plasma-Based Ion Implantation, 4-6 Aug. 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. B, Microelectron. Nanometer Struct. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: ion implantation|materials science|modelling|plasma diagnostics|plasma production|semiconductor doping
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B (Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the last five years, plasma source ion implantation (PSII) research at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, has encompassed work in the areas of plasma physics, diagnostics, ion-material interactions' modeling, materials science issues, and a broad spectrum of industrial applications of PSII technology. The third generation PSII system is presently under construction. Three methods of plasma generation, namely, electron impact method, glow discharge, and radio frequency have been successfully employed. In the following article the highlights of the above facets of PSII research activities have been presented
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation research; plasma physics; diagnostics; ion-material interactions' modeling; materials science issues; industrial applications; plasma source ion implantation technology; electron impact method; plasma generation,; glow discharge; radio frequency

z:row.TitlePrimary: Ion beam enhanced deposition of titanium-nitride on INCONEL 718
z:row.Keyword: Nickel Chromium Alloys -- Protective Coatings|Protective Coatings--Ceramics|Titanium Compounds--Chemical Vapor Deposition|Plasmas--Production|Superalloys--Spectroscopic Analysis|Spectroscopy, Auger Electron--Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A wear-resistant titanium nitride film was successfully formed on the commercial superalloy INCONEL 718 with a plasma source ion-implantation unit operated in the ion-beam-enhanced deposition mode. The process was carried out at ambient temperature by alternately depositing titanium with a dc cathode sputter source followed by nitrogen implantation utilizing a plasma. Auger spectroscopy was used to determine the composition-depth profile of the surface film. Transmission electron microscopy indicated the film to be adherent and fine-grained. Tribological property improvements are attributed to both higher hardness and lower coefficient of friction of the titanium nitride film.

z:row.Abstract: A tantalum-nitride film was successfully deposited at ambient temperature on copper with a modified ion-assisted-deposition (IAD) technique. The process uses an argon and nitrogen plasma to sputter deposit from a tantalum rf-cathode and ion implant the deposited film simultaneously. Both argon and nitrogen ions are used for sputtering and ion implantation. Auger spectroscopy and x-ray diffraction were used to characterize the resulting film.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structural analysis of silicon doped by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1993 MRS Fall Meeting, Nov 29-Dec 3 1992
z:row.Keyword: Semiconducting silicon|Crystal structure|Crystal lattices|Ion implantation|Plasma sources|Semiconductor doping|Boron|Annealing|Electromagnetic wave scattering|Surfaces|Crystal defects|Radiation damage|X ray analysis
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Materials Research Society, Pittsburgh, PA, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Boston, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We have used high resolution x-ray diffraction to analyze the structural changes that accompany boron doping of silicon by BF3 plasma source ion implantation (PSII). Triple crystal diffraction analysis of as-implanted PSII doped silicon showed little excess x-ray diffuse scattering, even when analyzed using the asymmetric (113) reflection for increased surface sensitivity. This result suggests that PSII is capable of providing high dose implantation with low damage. Annealing of the PSII-doped silicon showed the development of a compressive surface layer, indicated by enhanced x-ray scattering directed perpendicular to the surface. Virtually all of the scattering from the annealed samples was concentrated in the so-called 'surface streak' which arises due to dynamical diffraction from the perfect crystal Si structure. Little if any diffuse scattering due to kinematic scattering from crystal defects was detected. These observations indicate that plasma source doping can be used to achieve both a shallow implant depth and an extremely uniform incorporation of boron into the silicon lattice.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: X ray diffraction; X ray scattering; Crystal diffraction analysis; Surface streak

z:row.TitlePrimary: Elevated temperature nitrogen ion implantation of incoloy alloys 908 and 909 using the plasma source ion implantation process
z:row.Keyword: Superalloys -- Ion Implantation|Nitrogen|Iron Nickel Alloys - Diffusion|Thermal Diffusion - Solids
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Materials Science & Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma source ion implantation process has been applied to two Fe-Ni-based superalloys, Incoloy* alloys 908 and 909. Nitrogen was implanted at 53 keV to a dose of 3 × 1018 atoms cm-2 and the sample temperature was intentionally raised to approximately 550°C to promote thermal diffusion. Auger analysis for nitrogen concentration indicated a subsurface maximum, then a somewhat lower but constant value up to about 5 μm, followed by a decrease that was more characteristic of thermal diffusion. The matrix lattice parameter at the surface increased owing to nitrogen implantation, and both X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy indicated the formation of nitrides at the surface. Cyclic potentiodynamic corrosion tests in 0.01N NaCl solution showed that the resistance to localized corrosion, after implantation, increased for alloy 908, but for alloy 909 only some aspects of corrosion showed improvement. Significant improvements in hardness and wear resistance were achieved at the surface as a result of the implantation process. Possible strengthening mechanisms are discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Incoloy Alloy 908; Incoloy Alloy 909; Surface Modification

z:row.TitlePrimary: Influence of temperature on nitrogen ion implantation of incoloy alloys 908 and 909
z:row.TitleSecondary: Second International Conference on Plasma Surface Engineering - PSE '90, Sep 10-14 1990
z:row.Keyword: Metals And Alloys -- Ion Implantation|Metals And Alloys--Wear Resisting|Nitrogen|Microscopic Examination--Scanning Electron Microscopy|Nitrides|Titanium Compounds

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Ger
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Specimens of Incoloy alloys 908 and 909 were implanted with nitrogen at temperatures of 100 and 400°C to a dose of 7 × 1017 ions cm-2. Scanning Auger multiprobe (SAM) was used to determine the nitrogen concentration depth profiles, from which the retained doses were calculated. Microhardness measurements and pin-on-disk wear testing were performed to evaluate the surface property improvements. The thicknesses of implanted layers increased by about an order of magnitude when the temperature was elevated from 100 to 400°C. Higher surface hardness and wear resistance were also obtained in the higher temperature implantation. Transmission electron microscopy images showed distinct microstructural changes and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy showed the presence of nitrides of titanium, chromium and niobium at the implanted surface.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Incoloy Alloy 908; Incoloy Alloy 909; Scanning Auger Multiprobe; Microhardness; Pin-On-Disk Wear Testing; X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dose and dose rate effects on the structure of methane plasma source ion implanted 304 stainless steel
z:row.TitleTertiary: Mater. Sci. Eng. A, Struct. Mater., Prop. Microstruct. Process. (Switzerland)

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-aided Manuf., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Type 304 stainless steel was treated by methane plasma source ion implantation. The effects of implantation dose and dose rate on the microstructure have been investigated. The implantation was carried out at a target bias of -30 keV. Two different doses: 1.5×1017 and 3×1017 atoms cm-2, and three dose rates: 3.4, 6.8 and 15 μA cm-2 were used. Higher doses and lower dose rates favor the formation of crystalline structure in the form of Fe2C (at 3.4 μA cm-2), or a mixture of Fe2C and possibly Fe3C and/or (Fe,Cr)7C3 (at 6.8 μA cm-2). Higher dose rates and lower doses favor the development of an amorphous structure. The mechanism of phase transformation in the implanted layer and its dependence on dose and dose rate are discussed
z:row.User2: dose rate effects; 304 stainless steel; methane plasma source ion implantation; microstructure; crystalline structure; amorphous structure

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation: a new approach to ion beam modification of materials
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Sixth International Conference on Surface Modification of Metals by Ion Beams, Sep 12-16 1988
z:row.Keyword: Metals and Alloys -- Ion Implantation|Ion Beams--Measurements|Surfaces--Modification|Cutting Tools--Wear|Plasmas
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Materials Science & Engineering A: Structural Materials: Properties, Microstructure and Processing
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Riva del Garda, Italy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a nonline-of-sight technique for surface modification of materials which is optimized for ion implantation of non-planar targets in non-semiconductor applications. In PSII, targets to be implanted are placed directly in a plasma source chamber and are then pulse biased to high negative voltage (10-100 kV in our experiments). A thick ion matrix sheath forms around the target, and ions accelerate through the sheath drop and bombard the target from all sides simultaneously without the necessity of target manipulation. Compared with conventional ion implantation, PSII minimizes the problems of shadowing and excessive sputtering of the target material, which can severely limit the retained dose of the implanted ion species. An examination of the comparative economics of surface modification by PSII relative to conventional ion implantation indicates substantial reductions in operating costs, by virtue of the greater throughput possible with PSII.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma Source Ion Implantation; Implantation Chambers; Target Manipulation

Triple crystal diffraction analysis of as-implanted PSII doped silicon showed little excess X-ray diffuse scattering, even when analyzed using the asymmetric (113) reflection for increased surface sensitivity. z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source nitrogen ion implantation of Ti-6Al-4V
z:row.TitleSecondary: Papers on Interfaces and Surfaces of Titanium Materials - Presented at the 1988 TMS/AIME Meeting, Sep 25-29 1988
z:row.Keyword: Titanium Aluminum Vanadium Alloys -- Ion Implantation|Nitrogen|Titanium Metallography--Microstructures|Wear of Materials|Prosthetics--Materials
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Metallurgical Transactions A (Physical Metallurgy and Materials Science)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation of nitrogen into Ti-6Al-4V produces microstructures and properties which are comparable with those resulting from conventional line-of-sight implantation methods. A PSII facility is small, easy and economical to operate, provides a high throughput rate, is appropriate for in-house operation, and does not require target manipulation, beam rastering, or local target shielding for uniform implantation results. It offers a new cost-effective technology for ion implantation, particularly components of complicated shape such as many prosthetic devices. Sublimation/evaporation/sputtering arrangements can be accomodated to permit ion mixing implantation permitting implanted surfaces to be produced which optimize wear and corrosion characteristics. Electron diffraction indicates that TiN is formed as a result of the implantation, but energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) data suggest that the phase may be Ti(V)N.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Results from AMANDA
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|high-energy cosmic ray interactions|photomultipliers
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: EP-Div., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array (AMANDA) is a high-energy neutrino telescope operating at the geographic South Pole. It is a lattice of photomultiplier tubes buried deep in the polar ice. The primary goal of this detector is to discover astrophysical sources of high energy neutrinos. We describe the detector methods of operation and present results from the AMANDA-B10 prototype. We demonstrate the improved sensitivity of the current AMANDA-II detector. We conclude with an outlook to the envisioned sensitivity of the future IceCube detector
z:row.User2: AMANDA results; Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array; high-energy neutrino telescope; South Pole; photomultiplier tubes; polar ice; astrophysical sources; AMANDA-B10 prototype; AMANDA-II detector

z:row.Abstract: Reports the detection of upwardly propagating atmospheric neutrinos by the ice-based Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array (AMANDA). These results establish a technology with which to build a kilometre-scale neutrino observatory necessary for astrophysical observations

z:row.Abstract: In addition to being successfully used for ion implantation, the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) technique has been used to produce diamond-like carbon films. Homogeneous, adherent films were obtained on silicon and stainless steel substrates under 2 kV pulse bias voltages and 50 mtorr methane plasma pressure. Chemical composition analysis was made using Auger electron microscopy. Fretting wear tests and scratch tests were performed to study the tribological and adherent properties. Cross sectional TEM samples were prepared. The interfacial microstructures and chemical compositions were analyzed using transmission electron microscopy and scanning transmission electron microscopy

z:row.TitlePrimary: Stabilization of MHD modes in an axisymmetric magnetic mirror by applied RF waves and initial results of Phaedrus-B
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eleventh IAEA International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 13-20 Nov. 1986
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kyoto, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Phaedrus was operated as a three-cell axisymmetric tandem mirror with dual half-turn end cell antennas at the end cell midplanes. The device was converted to a five-cell tandem mirror (Phaedrus-B) with quadrupole end cells by adding choke coils at the ends of the central cell and dual half-turn antennas throughout the device. The axisymmetric Phaedrus operation achieved enhanced axial plugging which improved the central cell density to n=1×1013 cm-3, the peak plasma beta to 13% and nτp to 3×1010 cm-3. The MHD stability was enhanced by the radial ponderomotive force using ICRF at 1.3, 1.7 and 4 Ωi. A kinetic theory of RF stabilization has been developed which includes the effects of RF sideband modes. The results suggest that RF far fields `lean' on the device walls and RF near fields `lean' on the antennas. The results were found to be sensitive to the antenna kz spectrum. Thermal barrier potential dips were identified without active barrier pumping. Low frequency fluctuations were found to be sensitive to the phasing of the central cell antennas. Plugging was enhanced by the presence of end cell RF which was resonant only in the central cell
z:row.User2: MHD modes; axisymmetric magnetic mirror; RF waves; three-cell; dual half-turn end cell antennas; five-cell; choke coils; central cell density; peak plasma beta; radial ponderomotive force

z:row.TitlePrimary: Initial results from the tandem mirror Phaedrus
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 1-10 July 1980
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Brussels, Belgium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The tandem mirror Phaedrus was designed with the aim of testing RF-heating techniques for auxiliary heating, low-energy neutral-beam refuelling and confinement properties of tandem mirrors. Fundamental ion cyclotron heating has been used to increase plug energy content during stream gun start-up by a factor of 10. Second-harmonic ion cyclotron heating has generated strong ion-tail heating. Studies of the tandem configuration demonstrate the problem of magnetic-field error and techniques to minimize the problem. Stable tandem confinement has been achieved with fundamental hating in both end plugs
z:row.User2: tandem mirror Phaedrus; RF-heating techniques; auxiliary heating; low-energy neutral-beam refuelling; confinement; ion cyclotron heating; plug energy content; ion-tail heating; magnetic-field error

z:row.TitlePrimary: Recent experiments in the Phaedrus tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nucelar Fusion Research. Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference, 1-8 Sept. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|plasma confinement|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Baltimore, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A stable, steady tandem mirror plasma is sustained by RF alone in the Phaedrus tandem mirror experiment. RF trapping of central-cell stream provides plug fuelling and Monte Carlo simulations predict many of its characteristics. The MHD stability of the Phaedrus tandem mirror plasma is shown to be in agreement with predictions of pressure-weighted minimum-|B| stability theory. Reduction of the ion end loss flux due to electrostatic confinement of central-cell ions is observed both statically and dynamically. Direct fuelling of the plugs by gas puffing and RF trapping has also been demonstrated.-In addition, neutral-beam injection into RF-sustained plasmas is described; significant increases in diamagnetism and density have been obtained. Preliminary experiments with breakdown and heating with ECRF are also described
z:row.User2: Phaedrus tandem mirror; RF trapping; plug fuelling; Monte Carlo simulations; MHD stability; ion end loss flux; electrostatic confinement; neutral-beam injection

z:row.Abstract: We report on the analysis of air showers observed in coincidence by the Antarctic Muon and Neutrino detector array (AMANDA-B10) and the South Pole Air Shower Experiment (SPASE-1 and SPASE-2). We discuss the use of coincident events for calibration and survey of the deep AMANDA detector as well as the response of AMANDA to muon bundles. This analysis uses data taken during 1997 when both SPASE-1 and SPASE-2 were in operation to provide a stereo view of AMANDA

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA Collaboration, Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., Berkeley, CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array (AMANDA) is a high-energy neutrino telescope operating at the geographic South Pole. It is a lattice of photo-multiplier tubes buried deep in the polar ice between 1500 and 2000 m. The primary goal of this detector is to discover astrophysical sources of high-energy neutrinos. A high-energy muon neutrino coming through the earth from the Northern Hemisphere can be identified by the secondary muon moving upward through the detector. The muon tracks are reconstructed with a maximum likelihood method. It models the arrival times and amplitudes of Cherenkov photons registered by the photo-multipliers. This paper describes the different methods of reconstruction, which have been successfully implemented within AMANDA. Strategies for optimizing the reconstruction performance and rejecting background are presented. For a typical analysis procedure the direction of tracks are reconstructed with about 2° accuracy

z:row.TitlePrimary: The IceCube prototype string in Amanda
z:row.TitleTertiary: Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. A, Accel. Spectrom. Detect. Assoc. Equip. (Netherlands)
z:row.Keyword: astronomical telescopes|Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|muon detection|neutrino detection|photomultipliers
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section A (Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array (Amanda) is a high-energy neutrino telescope. It is a lattice of optical modules (OM) installed in the clear ice below the South Pole Station. Each OM contains a photomultiplier tube (PMT) that detects photons of Cherenkov light generated in the ice by muons and electrons. IceCube is a cubic-kilometer-sized expansion of Amanda currently being built at the South Pole. In IceCube the PMT signals are digitized already in the optical modules and transmitted to the surface. A prototype string of 41 OMs equipped with this new all-digital technology was deployed in the Amanda array in the year 2000. In this paper we describe the technology and demonstrate that this string serves as a proof of concept for the IceCube array. Our investigations show that the OM timing accuracy is 5ns. Atmospheric muons are detected in excellent agreement with expectations with respect to both angular distribution and absolute rate. [All rights reserved Elsevier]
z:row.User2: ICECUBE prototype string; AMANDA; Antarctic Muon And Neutrino Detector Array; high-energy neutrino telescope; optical modules; photomultiplier tube; Cherenkov light; digitized PMT signals; all-digital technology; atmospheric muon detection; angular distribution; absolute rate

z:row.Abstract: A comprehensive study of the microstructural effects of nitrogen ion implantation on Ti-6Al-4V alloy has been carried out. The work was promoted by the fact that the corrosive wear resistance of Ti-6Al-4V alloy in an environment similar to that encountered in medical applications can be considerably improved by nitrogen ion implantation using the plasma source ion implantation technique. The alloy was implanted with 50 keV nitrogen ions to different doses ranging from 9×1020 to 1×1022 atoms/m2. Composition distribution within the implanted region was characterized by Auger electron spectroscopy. Microstructural studies were based on transmission electron microscopy. Better understanding of the wear/corrosion behavior is obtained from the study of the microstructures resulting from implantation and provides guidelines for further improvement of the wear/corrosion properties of Ti-6Al-4V alloy
z:row.User2: composition distribution; microstructural effects; ion implantation; corrosive wear resistance; plasma source; doses; Auger electron spectroscopy; transmission electron microscopy; 50 keV; TiAlV:N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Computer simulation of ion beam mixing
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Ninth International Conference on Ion Beam Analysis, Jun 26-30 1989

z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Nucl Instrum Methods Phys Res Sect B
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Kingston, Ont, Can
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A highly optimized dynamic Monte Carlo program TAMIX has been developed to simulate the ion beam mixing process. In addition to the collisional features, some of the diffusional processes are taken into account in TAMIX for elevated temperature irradiation applications. TAMIX can be run in three modes, i.e. Static mode, collisional dynamic mode, and collisional-diffusional dynamic mode. TAMIX is a non-analog vectorized Monte Carlo program for the full use of the capability of vector computers such as the Cray. In TAMIX, sophisticated models have been adopted to obtain both speed and accuracy, including tabulation of the scattering angles, energy-dependent mean free path for nuclear collisions, 'random surface model' for sputtering, and concentration-dependent surface binding energies. The simulation results applied to a wide range of situations show good agreement with experimental data.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Software Package TAMIX; Ion Beam Mixing

z:row.Abstract: With an effective telescope area of order 104 m2 for TeV neutrinos, a threshold near ~50 GeV and a pointing accuracy of 2.5 degrees per muon track, the AMANDA detector represents the first of a new generation of high energy neutrino telescopes, reaching a scale envisaged over 25 years ago. We describe early results on the calibration of natural deep ice as a particle detector as well as on AMANDA's performance as a neutrino telescope

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper briefly summarizes the search for astronomical sources of high-energy neutrinos using the AMANDA-B10 detector. The complete data set from 1997 was analyzed. For Eμ>10 TeV, the detector exceeds 10000 m2 in effective area between declinations of 25 and 90 degrees. Neutrinos generated in the atmosphere by cosmic ray interactions were used to verify the overall sensitivity of the detector. The absolute pointing accuracy and angular resolution has been confirmed by the analysis of coincident events between the SPASE air shower array and the AMANDA detector. Preliminary flux limits from point source candidates are presented. For declinations larger than +45 degrees, our results compare favorably to existing limits for sources in the Southern sky. We also present the current status of the searches for high energy neutrino emission from diffusely distributed sources, gamma-ray bursters and WIMPs from the center of the earth
z:row.User2: AMANDA; high energy neutrino detector; AMANDA-B10 detector; sensitivity; pointing accuracy; angular resolution; SPASE; gamma-ray bursters; WIMP; diffusely distributed sources

z:row.TitlePrimary: Results from the Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array
z:row.TitleSecondary: 20th International Conference on Neutrino Physics and Astrophysics, 25-30 May 2002
z:row.Keyword: Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|gamma-ray sources (astronomical)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Munich, Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: We show new results from both the older and newer incarnations of AMANDA (AMANDA-B10 and AMANDA-II, respectively). These results demonstrate that AMANDA is a functioning, multipurpose detector with significant physics and astrophysics reach. They include a new higher-statistics measurement of the atmospheric muon neutrino flux and preliminary results from searches for a variety of sources of ultrahigh energy neutrinos: generic point sources, gamma-ray bursters and diffuse sources producing muons in the detector, and diffuse sources producing electromagnetic or hadronic showers in or near the detector
z:row.User2: AMANDA; AMANDA-B10; electromagnetic showers; hadronic showers; AMANDA-II; Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array; atmospheric muon neutrino flux; ultrahigh energy neutrinos; point sources; gamma-ray bursters

z:row.TitlePrimary: IceCube - the next generation neutrino telescope at the South Pole
z:row.TitleSecondary: 20th International Conference on Neutrino Physics and Astrophysics, 25-30 May 2002
z:row.Keyword: astronomical telescopes|Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|galactic nuclei|gamma-ray sources (astronomical)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Munich, Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Lawrence Berkely Nat. Lab., Berkeley, CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: IceCube is a large neutrino telescope of the next generation to be constructed in the Antarctic Ice Sheet near the South Pole. We present the conceptual design and the sensitivity of the IceCube detector to predicted fluxes of neutrinos, both atmospheric and extra-terrestrial. A complete simulation of the detector design has been used to study the detector's capability to search for neutrinos from sources such as active galaxies, and gamma-ray bursts
z:row.User2: IceCube; neutrino telescope; atmospheric neutrino; active galaxies; gamma-ray bursts

z:row.TitlePrimary: New results from the AMANDA Neutrino Telescope
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray energy spectra|cosmic ray origin|high-energy cosmic ray interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA Collaboration, Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array (AMANDA) is a Cerenkov telescope which uses the south polar ice cap to search for neutrinos from extraterrestrial sources. We present a preliminary reconstruction of the energy spectrum of atmospheric neutrinos above a few TeV and several recent results on searches for high-energy astrophysical neutrinos, both non-localized and emitted by point-like sources. [All rights reserved Elsevier]
z:row.User2: AMANDA neutrino telescope; Antarctic Muon and Neutrino Detector Array; Cerenkov telescope; south polar ice cap; extraterrestrial neutrino sources; atmospheric neutrino energy spectrum; high-energy astrophysical neutrinos; point-like sources

z:row.TitleSecondary: Sixth Topical Seminar on Neutrino and Astroparticle Physics, 17-21 May 1999

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Pisa, Italy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. fuer Hochenergiephys., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, Zeuthen, Germany
z:row.Abstract: The first stage of the AMANDA high energy neutrino detector at the south pole, the 302 PMT array AMANDA-B10, is taking data since 1997. We describe results on atmospheric neutrinos, limits on indirect WIMP detection, seasonal muon flux variation, relativistic monopole flux limits, a search for gravitational collapse neutrinos, and a depth scan of the optical ice properties. The next stage 19-string detector AMANDA-II with ~650 PMTs will be completed in spring 2000

z:row.TitlePrimary: Limits to the muon flux from WIMP annihilation in the center of the Earth with the AMANDA detector
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray muons|cosmic ray neutrinos|dark matter|geophysical aspects of cosmic rays|sparticles
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. of Phys., Mainz Univ., Germany
z:row.Abstract: A search for nearly vertical up-going muon-neutrinos from neutralino annihilations in the center of the Earth has been performed with the AMANDA-B10 neutrino detector. The data collected in 130.1 days of live time in 1997, ~109 events, have been analyzed for this search. No excess over the expected atmospheric neutrino background has been observed. An upper limit at 90% confidence level has been obtained on the annihilation rate of neutralinos in the center of the Earth, as well as the corresponding muon flux limit, both as a function of the neutralino mass in the range 100 GeV-5000 GeV
z:row.User2: WIMP annihilation; AMANDA detector; muon flux; nearly vertical up-going muon-neutrinos; neutralino annihilations; atmospheric neutrino background; muon flux limit; neutralino mass

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search for extraterrestrial point sources of high energy neutrinos with AMANDA-II using data collected in 2000-2002
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray energy spectra|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|high-energy cosmic ray interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA, Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab.,, CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The results of a search for point sources of high energy neutrinos in the northern hemisphere using data collected by AMANDA-II in the years 2000, 2001, and 2002 are presented. In particular, a comparison with the single-year result previously published shows that the sensitivity was improved by a factor of 2.2. The muon neutrino flux upper limits on selected candidate sources, corresponding to an Eν-2 neutrino energy spectrum, are included. Sky grids were used to search for possible excesses above the background of cosmic ray induced atmospheric neutrinos. This search reveals no statistically significant excess for the three years considered
z:row.User2: extraterrestrial point sources; high energy neutrinos; AMANDA-II; AD 2000 to 2002; northern hemisphere; single-year result; muon neutrino flux upper limits; neutrino energy spectrum; sky grids; cosmic ray induced atmospheric neutrinos

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of high energy atmospheric neutrinos with the Antarctic muon and neutrino detector array
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray muons|cosmic ray neutrinos|geophysical aspects of cosmic rays|high-energy cosmic ray interactions|Monte Carlo methods
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Bartol Res. Inst., Delaware Univ., Newark, DE, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Antarctic muon and neutrino detector array (AMANDA) began collecting data with ten strings in 1997. Results from the first year of operation are presented. Neutrinos coming through the Earth from the Northern Hemisphere are identified by secondary muons moving upward through the array. Cosmic rays in the atmosphere generate a background of downward moving muons, which are about 106 times more abundant than the upward moving muons. Over 130 days of exposure, we observed a total of about 300 neutrino events. In the same period, a background of 1.05×109 cosmic ray muon events was recorded. The observed neutrino flux is consistent with atmospheric neutrino predictions. Monte Carlo simulations indicate that 90% of these events lie in the energy range 66 GeV to 3.4 TeV. The observation of atmospheric neutrinos consistent with expectations establishes AMANDA-B10 as a working neutrino telescope
z:row.User2: high energy atmospheric neutrinos; AMANDA; Earth; secondary muons; downward moving muons; cosmic ray muon; Monte Carlo simulations; 130 day; 66 GeV to 3.4 TeV

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search for neutrino-induced cascades with the AMANDA detector
z:row.Keyword: astronomical techniques|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|cosmic ray showers|energy loss of particles
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AMANDA Collaboration, Lawrence Berkeley Nat. Lab., CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: We report on a search for electromagnetic and/or hadronic showers (cascades) induced by a diffuse flux of neutrinos with energies between 5 TeV and 300 TeV from extraterrestrial sources. Cascades may be produced by matter interactions of all flavors of neutrinos, and contained cascades have better energy resolution and afford better background rejection than throughgoing νμ-induced muons. Data taken in 1997 with the AMANDA detector were searched for events with a high-energy cascadelike signature. The observed events are consistent with expected backgrounds from atmospheric neutrinos and catastrophic energy losses from atmospheric muons. Effective volumes for all flavors of neutrinos, which allow the calculation of limits for any neutrino flux model, are presented. The limit on cascades from a diffuse flux of νe+νμ+ντ+ν¯e+ν¯μ+ν¯τ is E2(dΦ/dE)(dΦ/dE)-6 GeV cm-2 s-1 sr-1, assuming a neutrino flavor flux ratio of 1:1:1 at the detector. The limit on cascades from a diffuse flux of νe+ν¯e is E2(dΦ/dE)(dΦ/dE)-6 GeV cm-2 s-1 sr-1, independent of the assumed neutrino flavor flux ratio
z:row.User2: neutrino-induced cascades; AMANDA detector; electromagnetic showers; hadronic showers; matter interactions; neutrino flavor flux ratio; extraterrestrial sources; background rejection; atmospheric neutrinos; catastrophic energy losses; atmospheric muons; neutrino flux model

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dynamics of collisional pulsed planar sheaths
z:row.TitleTertiary: Phys. Rev. E, Stat. Phys. Plasmas Fluids Relat. Interdiscip. Top. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: fluorescence|ion implantation|plasma applications|plasma collision processes|plasma diagnostics|plasma sheaths|plasma-wall interactions
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Physical Review E (Statistical Physics, Plasmas, Fluids, and Related Interdisciplinary Topics)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Eng. Res. Center for Plasma-Aided Manuf., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper presents experimental measurements of a high-voltage collisional pulsed sheath. Such high-voltage pulsed sheaths are now commonly used for implanting material surfaces. These laser induced-fluorescence measurements are used to test the predictive capability of two recent models of pulsed sheaths. It is found that the current models are incomplete and fail to predict accurately the experimental measurements. It is deduced from the data that these models fail primarily because they do not take into account ion production by secondary electrons. This ion production influences both the temporal development of pulsed sheaths and the ion impact energy profile. These influences might be vitally important to some manufacturing processes and so must be included in any accurate model of the system
z:row.User2: collisional pulsed planar sheaths; high-voltage collisional pulsed sheath; material surface implantation; laser induced-fluorescence; pulsed sheaths; ion production; secondary electrons; temporal development; ion impact energy profile; manufacturing processes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Limits on diffuse fluxes of high energy extraterrestrial neutrinos with the AMANDA-B10 detector
z:row.Keyword: cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray energy spectra|cosmic ray neutrinos|geophysical aspects of cosmic rays|neutrino oscillations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. of Phys., Univ. of Mainz, Germany
z:row.Abstract: Data from the AMANDA-B10 detector taken during the austral winter of 1997 have been searched for a diffuse flux of high energy extraterrestrial muon neutrinos. This search yielded no excess events above those expected from background atmospheric neutrinos, leading to upper limits on the extraterrestrial neutrino flux measured at the earth. For an assumed E-2 spectrum, a 90% classical confidence level upper limit has been placed at a level E2Φ(E)=8.4×10-7 cm-2 s-1 sr-1 GeV (for a predominant neutrino energy range 6-1000 TeV), which is the most restrictive bound placed by any neutrino detector. Some specific predicted model spectra are excluded. Interpreting these limits in terms of the flux from a cosmological distributions of sources requires the incorporation of neutrino oscillations, typically weakening the limits by a factor of 2
z:row.User2: AMANDA-B10 detector; diffuse fluxes; AD 1997; background atmospheric neutrinos; high energy extraterrestrial muon neutrinos; upper limits; extraterrestrial neutrino flux; neutrino energy range; cosmological source distribution; model spectra; neutrino oscillations; 6 to 1000 TeV

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search for extraterrestrial point sources of neutrinos with AMANDA-II
z:row.Keyword: active galaxies|BL Lac-type objects|cosmic ray neutrinos
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Inst. of Phys., Univ. of Mainz, Germany
z:row.Abstract: We present the results of a search for point sources of high-energy neutrinos in the northern hemisphere using AMANDA-II data collected in the year 2000. Included are flux limits on several active-galactic-nuclei blazars, microquasars, magnetars, and other candidate neutrino sources. A search for excesses above a random background of cosmic-ray-induced atmospheric neutrinos and misreconstructed downgoing cosmic-ray muons reveals no statistically significant neutrino point sources. We show that AMANDA-II has achieved the sensitivity required to probe known TeV γ-ray sources such as the blazar Markarian 501 in its 1997 flaring state at a level where neutrino and γ-ray fluxes are equal

z:row.TitlePrimary: Laser-induced fluorescence measurement of the dynamics of a pulsed planar sheath
z:row.Keyword: Plasma diagnostics|Plasma density|Fluorescence|Nitrogen|Electrodes|Ion implantation|Laser beams|Velocity|Probes|Electric fields|Mathematical models|Three dimensional|Position measurement
z:row.Publisher: American Inst of Physics, Woodbury, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The laser-induced fluorescence measurement is a plasma diagnostic technique which measures the ion density and the position of the sheath edge. In this paper, a study is conducted to apply this technique to the measurement of the propagation of a pulsed plasma sheath produced by a high voltage step-like potential to a cathodic planar electrode or ion target. The results from the study was compared to the predictions of the two fluid theory of pulsed plasma sheath. It was observed that for distances greater than 0.5 ion mean free paths, the agreement deteriorates.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radial transport in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1988. Proceedings of the Twelfth International Conference Held by the International Atomic Energy Agency, 12-19 Oct. 1988
z:row.TitleTertiary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1988. Proceedings of the Twelfth International Conference Held by the International Atomic Energy Agency
z:row.Keyword: magnetic traps|plasma devices|plasma radiofrequency heating|plasma transport processes
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Nice, France
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Application of ICRF in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror end cells can result in increases in central cell plasma density by as much as a factor of three. Central cell peak densities of about 6×1012 cm-3 have been achieved along with thermal barrier-like axial density and potential profiles. Recent analysis of the data shows that an improvement in the plasma confinement occurs in both the radial and axial directions. In the core plasma, the density rise results from axial plugging; in the edge, radial loss is reduced. Detailed measurements of the potential structures and the electron end loss indicate that RF heating of electrons parallel to the magnetic field plays a dominant role in controlling the radial, as well as the axial, potential profiles. The radial potential profile has been measured to be hollow. Both electron and ion diffusion coefficients either remain the same or increase when end cell RF systems are operated. Radial potential trapping of ions in the plasma is the reason for the increase in radial confinement. Azimuthally asymmetric potential profiles have been measured in the thermal barriers, consistent with enhanced radial loss or `pumping' in this region. In addition, the electron end loss is measured to be azimuthally asymmetric. While the diffusion of the ions and the electrons in the entire plasma column is tied to the azimuthal asymmetries in the potentials, the density increases are correlated with the radial ion potential well
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-B tandem mirror end cells; central cell plasma density; thermal barrier-like axial density; potential profiles; plasma confinement; core plasma; density; axial plugging; radial loss; electron end loss; RF heating; ion diffusion coefficients; azimuthal asymmetries; radial ion potential well

z:row.TitlePrimary: Improved MHD stabilization in the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror obtained by using ICRF excited by rotating field antennas and measurements of a model antenna near fields
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1988. Proceedings of the Twelfth International Conference Held by the International Atomic Energy Agency, 12-19 Oct. 1988
