z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Rotating field antennas are used to achieve ponderomotive stability of interchange modes at RF frequencies ω below the ion cyclotron frequency Ωi, and measurements are made of mode conversion associated with the non-uniform axisymmetric mirror field. By rapidly changing the plasma's MHD stability during a discharge through an abrupt change in the phasing of antennas separated by 1 m, it is found that at ω/Ωi=1.25 the sideband modes reduce the stabilizing ponderomotive force by 40%. The linear damping rate associated with the ponderomotive stabilization is measured and found to agree with theory. Recent experiments measure the three components of the ICRF B fields near a model Faraday shielded ICRF antenna placed in the central cell
z:row.User2: MHD stabilization; Phaedrus-B tandem mirror; ICRF; rotating field antennas; model antenna; ponderomotive stability; interchange modes; mode conversion; axisymmetric mirror field; sideband modes; linear damping rate; B fields; Faraday shielded ICRF antenna

z:row.TitlePrimary: Sheath dynamics and dose analysis for planar targets in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A comparison of the experimental measurements and numerical calculations of temporal and spatial sheath evolution for planar targets is presented. The propagating sheath edge initially emanates in an ellipsoidal shape elongated along the plane of the target, then transforms to a spherical shape at a distance of about one diameter from the target, and ultimately the sheath becomes stationary at a distance that depends on the plasma parameters and target dimensions. To complement sheath expansion measurements with dose uniformity in planar targets, silicon wafers were implanted with nitrogen. Surface profilometry and scanning Auger microprobe measurements showed greater sputtering and shallower implantation depths at the edge of the wafer, relative to the centre, in qualitative agreement with the sheath expansion measurements
z:row.User2: sheath dynamics; surface profilometry; dose analysis; planar targets; plasma source ion implantation; experimental measurements; numerical calculations; scanning Auger microprobe measurements; sputtering

z:row.TitlePrimary: Low-cost substrates
z:row.Keyword: dielectric thin films|laminates|permittivity|polymer films|printed circuit design|printed circuit manufacture|printed circuit testing|thermal analysis
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: AlliedSignal Laminate Syst. Inc., La Crosse, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Traditional laminates and prepregs continue to meet most PCB needs, but rapidly developing new products demand substrates with better dielectric and thermal properties. Pentium II, K-6, and faster processors may not achieve full potential with FR-4 substrates and designs. PCBs with lower dielectric constants (Dk) are needed for faster signal speeds in advanced work stations, test instruments, oscilloscopes, and other devices. Higher processor speeds and increased functions generate temperatures requiring PCBs with improved heat tolerance. PCBs with lower dissipation factors (Df) run cooler, because less power is dissipated into the substrate. Telecommunications switches, network servers, satellite communications, modems, and similar applications may also be limited by Dk. While processing speed is important, many of these applications must handle faint signals without loss of fidelity, so low-Df PCBs may be crucial, and in all these situations, cost must be kept in mind. FR-408 laminate, with its homogeneous thermoset polymer system and FR-4 processing characteristics, provides a new cost/performance benchmark for PCB substrates
z:row.User2: low-cost substrates; laminates; prepregs; PCBs; thermal properties; dielectric properties; Pentium II processors; K-6 processors; FR-4 substrates; PCB dielectric constants; signal speed; work stations; test instruments; oscilloscopes; processor speed; PCB heat tolerance; PCB power dissipation factors; telecommunications switches; network servers; satellite communications; modems; faint signals; signal fidelity; PCB cost; FR-408 laminate; homogeneous thermoset polymer system; FR-4 processing characteristics; PCB substrates; cost/performance benchmark

z:row.TitlePrimary: Physics and operation of the AMANDA-II high energy neutrino telescope
z:row.TitleSecondary: Particle Astrophysics Instrumentation, 22-23 Aug. 2002
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proc. SPIE - Int. Soc. Opt. Eng. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: Cherenkov counters|cosmic ray apparatus|cosmic ray neutrinos|cosmic ray origin|gamma-ray sources (astronomical)|neutrino detection
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Waikoloa, HI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: California Univ., Irvine, CA, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper briefly describes the principle of operation and science goals of the AMANDA high energy neutrino telescope located at the South Pole, Antarctica. Results from an earlier phase of the telescope, called AMANDA-B10, demonstrate both reliable operation and the broad astrophysical reach of this device, which includes searches for a variety of sources of ultrahigh energy neutrinos: generic point sources, gamma-ray bursts and diffuse sources. The predicted sensitivity and angular resolution of the telescope were confirmed by studies of atmospheric muon and neutrino backgrounds. We also report on the status of the analysis from AMANDA-II, a larger version with far greater capabilities. At this stage of analysis, details of the ice properties and other systematic uncertainties of the AMANDA-II telescope are under study, but we have made progress toward critical science objectives. In particular, we focus on the search for continuous emission from astrophysical point sources and the search for correlated neutrino emission from gamma ray bursts detected by BATSE before decommissioning in May 2000. During the next two years, we expect to exploit the full potential of AMANDA-II with the installation of a new data acquisition system that records full waveforms from the in-ice optical sensors
z:row.User2: AMANDA-II; operation; atmospheric neutrino; correlated neutrino emission; BATSE; high energy neutrino telescope; point sources; gamma-ray bursts; sensitivity; angular resolution; atmospheric muon; cosmic ray neutrino; measurement technique; cosmic ray apparatus; cosmic ray source; AMANDA

z:row.TitlePrimary: BEAMLET STEERING BY APERTURE DISPLACEMENT IN ION SOURCES WITH LARGE ACCELERATION-DECELERATION RATIO
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The steering of ion beamlets by aperture displacement is studied analytically and numerically for the case of triode extractors with large acceleration-deceleration ratios. Both slit and round apertures are examined. When the second-order effects of space charge and potential sag in the extractor are included in the analysis, good agreement with numerical simulations is obtained.

z:row.TitlePrimary: FABRICATION OF EXTRACTOR GRIDS FOR NEUTRAL BEAM SOURCES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: The fabrication of tungsten wires for use in extractor grids on neutral beam ion sources is described. The tungsten wires are machined from 0. 152-cm-diam tungsten wires into triangular wires by a three-step grinding process. These grid wires have been used in the neutral beam sources for Phaedrus (6 keV beams) and for the Wisconsin Levitated Octupole (15 keV beams). The beam angular divergence is comparable to that obtained from commercially supplied grid wires.

z:row.Abstract: A simple method for fabricating filament chucks for multifilament ion sources is described. The chucks can be readily machined at a fraction of the cost of commercially available chucks.

z:row.TitlePrimary: ION BEAMLET STEERING BY APERTURE DISPLACEMENT IN TWO-STAGE ACCELERATORS

z:row.Abstract: The steering of ion beamlets by aperture displacement in two-stage four-grid accelerators is examined using a model previously developed for single-stage three-grid accelerators with large acceleration-deceleration ratio. The analysis (which includes the second order effects of space charge and the effect of potential sag due to finite aperture radius) is found to be in good agreement with experimental data from two-stage accelerators.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Carbon ion implantation of pure iron
z:row.Keyword: electron microscope examination of materials|ion implantation|iron|plasma applications|surface hardening|wear
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Carbon can be successfully implanted in iron using a methane plasma and the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) process. The double shoulder accompanying the main carbon peak in the Auger broad scan spectra indicates that the carbon is present mainly in the carbide state. This is supported by electron microscopy investigations where a uniform distribution of spherical carbides was observed in the implanted layer. These carbides were identified as Fe2C, a phase unique to the ion implantation process. The surface strengthening and improvement in wear resistance of pure iron due to PSII-carbon implantation is attributed to the formation of the hard iron carbide phase at the surface
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; methane plasma; electron microscopy; surface strengthening; wear resistance; carbide phase; Fe2C; Fe; C ion implantation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surface modification of monel K-500 by the plasma source ion implantation process
z:row.TitleSecondary: 16th International Conference on Metallurgical Coatings (ICMC) - Part 2 (of 3), Apr 17-21 1989
z:row.Keyword: Coatings -- Plasma Spraying|Nickel Copper Alloys--Ion Implantation|Surfaces--Modification|Nitrides--Wear Resisting
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII), a non-line-of-sight technology for implanting preferably gaseous species, is a new and innovative approach to surface modification of materials. The principal objective of the present investigation was to apply PSII technology to improve the wear characteristics of monels for developing a new class of bearing materials operating in highly magnetic environments. Monel K-500 alloy samples were nitrogen implanted by the PSII process and the modified layers were characterized by profilometry and optical metallography, low load microhardness testing, scanning Auger microscopy (SAM), pin-on-disk wear testing and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The results of nitrogen implantation show a significant improvement in wear resistance of this alloy without any perceptible increase in surface hardness.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma Source Ion Implantation; Monels; Nitrogen Implantation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structure and wear properties of carbon implanted 304 stainless steel using plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Keyword: Stainless steel|Ion implantation|Carbon|Microstructure|Wear of materials|Mechanical properties|Plasma applications
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Elsevier Science Publ Co Inc, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Methane plasma source ion implantation was used to implant carbon ions into 304 stainless steel. This paper examines the effects of high voltage pulse repetition rate on the structure and wear properties of implanted samples. The implantations were carried out at a target bias of -30 keV to a dose of 3 × 1017 atoms cm-2. Three repetition rates (42 Hz, 87 Hz and 126 Hz) were used. At low repetition rate, a carbon coated-implanted surface forms, while only an implanted surface is produced at high repetition rates. Metastable phases were observed and identified, and the microstructure at the surface was observed to be dependent on the chosen implantation parameters. Fe2C formed in the implantation layer which is produced at 42 Hz. Smaller size Fe2C and other forms of carbides (possibly Fe3C and/or (Cr, Fe)7C3) formed in samples implanted at 87 Hz. An increase in repetition rate to 126 Hz produced a shallower amorphous implantation layer. Possible explanations of phase formation mechanisms are given. Wear resistance of all the implanted samples was improved, with the coated-implanted sample produced at 42 Hz showing the greatest improvement. The mechanism of wear was observed to change from an adhesive mode to a mild abrasive mode after implantation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Chromium plating pollution source reduction by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Keyword: Chromium plating|Pollution control|Environmental protection|Plasma sources|Ion implantation|Occupational risks|Tribology|Hardening|Corrosion resistance|Auger electron spectroscopy|Chemical analysis|Wear resistance|Materials testing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: There is growing concern over the environmental and workers' health issues due to the chemical baths and rinse water used in the hard chromium plating process. In this regard the significant hardening response of chromium to nitrogen ion implantation can be environmentally beneficial from the standpoint of decreasing the thickness and the frequency of application of chromium plating. In this paper the results of a study of nitrogen ion implantation of chrome-plated test flats using the non-line-of-sight plasma source ion implantation (PSII) process are discussed. Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) showed the implanted layer thickness to be about 2000 angstrom. Electron spectroscopy for chemical analysis (ESCA) indicated the formation of chromium nitride phase in the implanted layer. The wear resistance improves after implantation owing to both surface hardening and a decrease in coefficient of friction. Corrosion resistance in saline solution improved moderately after PSII treatment.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Chromium plating pollution source reduction; Plasma source ion implantation; Electron spectroscopy for chemical analysis; Coefficient of friction; Chemical baths

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation: A new, cost-effective, non-line-of-sight technique for ion implantation of materials
z:row.TitleSecondary: 15th International Conference on Metallurgical Coatings - ICMC, Apr 11-15 1988
z:row.Keyword: Surfaces -- Ion Implantation|Plasmas--Ion Sources|Silicon and Alloys--Ion Implantation|Steel--Ion Implantation|Metals and Alloys--Mechanical Properties|Ion Beams--Applications
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Surface modification by ion bombardment is a well-established technique for improving the hardness, friction, wear resistance and corrosion resistance of materials. We are developing a new technique, plasma source ion implantation (PSII), which circumvents the line-of-sight restriction of conventional ion implantation. In PSII, targets to be implanted are placed directly in a plasma source chamber and are then pulse biased to high negative voltage (10-100 kV in our experiments). A thick, ion matrix sheath forms around the target, and ions accelerate through the sheath drop and bombard the target from all sides simultaneously without the necessity of target manipulation. PSII produces a deposition profile characteristic of high energy ion implantation. Our experiments have demonstrated that PSII efficiently implants ions to the concentrations and depths required for surface modification, and produces material with improved microhardness and wear properties. Ion implantation of silicon, steel, and pierce punches, as well as the resulting modified surface properties, are discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Nitrogen Ion Plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Surface modification of Ti-6Al-4V surgical alloy by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Keyword: Titanium Aluminum Vanadium Alloys -- Medical Applications|Surfaces - Modification|Nitrogen - Ion Implantation|Tribology
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) was applied to Ti-6Al-4V surgical alloy to improve its tribological properties. Nitrogen implantation at room temperature produced an improvement in wear resistance. Implantation at an elevated temperature (approximately 600°C) resulted in a substantially thicker modified surface layer with sustained wear resistance. The best results were obtained by a two-step process wherein elevated temperature implantation was followed by room temperature implantation. The tribological properties resulting from this two-step process surpassed those of the Co-Cr alloy and were comparable with those obtained by ion nitriding. The base material properties remained unchanged after the PSII treatments. The surface properties were characterized using low-load microhardness measurements, pin-on-disk wear testing and Auger spectroscopy.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma Source Ion Implantation; Surgical Alloys

z:row.TitlePrimary: A technique for determination of microhardness profiles in thin surface diffusion layers
z:row.TitleSecondary: 2nd International Symposium on Trends and New Applications in Thin Films (TATF 89), 27 Feb.-3 March 1989
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Regensburg, West Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The technique described allows for the accumulation of multiple data points in a thin diffusion layer. The sample is mounted so that the top surface rather than the cross-section is exposed. The sample is then polished incrementally and microhardness measurements made at different depths beneath the surface as polishing proceeds. The exact depth of the layer removed during polishing is monitored by making a reference Knoop indentation with the largest load available and measuring the decrease in its long diagonal length at different stages of polishing. The authors have established the usefulness of this technique using diffusion layers produced by two different types of process
z:row.User2: microhardness profiles; surface diffusion layers; polishing; Knoop indentation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Technique for determination of microhardness profiles in thin surface diffusion layers
z:row.Keyword: Iron Nickel Alloys -- Thin Films|Nitrogen--Diffusion|Films--Mechanical Properties|Wear of Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A number of surface modification techniques involve diffusion of a foreign species into the host matrix to produce a hard, wear-resistant diffusion layer on the surface. In these cases, determination of the microhardness gradient across the diffusion layer is frequently of importance. In the technique described in the present communication The sample is mounted so that the top surface rather than the cross-section is exposed. Microhardness measurements are made on the top surface. The sample is then polished incrementally (with 1 μm diamond paste) with microhardness measurements being made at different depths beneath the surface as polishing proceeds. Hardness measurements are made with lower loads (100 g) in the vicinity of the reference indentation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Microhardness Profiles; Surface Diffusion Layers

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design of pumped neutralizers for neutral beams using Monte Carlo methods
z:row.TitleSecondary: American Nuclear Society 1982 Winter Meeting, 14-18 Nov. 1982
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|Monte Carlo methods
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Washington, DC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Gas cell neutralizers for neutral beam injectors generate large quantities of room temperature neutral gas. This gas must be pumped by the beamline vacuum system to avoid deleterious effects on the target plasma confinement experiment. In a conventional neutral beam system, the neutralizer is merely a duct that serves to impede the flow of gas coming from the ion source to form a gas cell. The authors refer to this type of neutralizer as a `passive' neutralizer. The pumping method considered is the `pumped' neutralizer. The neutralizer is constructed to have vanes (Venetian blinds) on its top and bottom faces. Particles that hit the vanes will have a tendency to be reflected back toward the ion source or reflected up into the ballast pumping volume. The walls of the ballast pumping volume are cryogenic and/or getter pumping surfaces. A Monte Carlo program has been written to investigate the effectiveness of a two-dimensional pumped neutralizer, i.e., a neutralizer with finite length and height but infinite width
z:row.User2: pumped neutralizers; neutral beams; Monte Carlo methods; beamline vacuum system; target plasma confinement experiment; ballast pumping volume

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear behavior of surgical Ti-6Al-4V alloy by plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Wear of Materials, Apr 7-11 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: Wear of Materials: International Conference on Wear of Materials

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Orlando, FL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen ion implantation by Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII) was conducted on surgical Ti-6Al-4V alloy in different implanted conditions including variations in dose, ion energy and target temperature. The performance of the implanted alloy was characterized by measurements of wear behavior. Consideration of the wear results showed that the wear behavior is related to different failure criteria which should be determined after a careful failure analysis.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Study of the relationship between wear rate and nitrogen concentration profile and application to plasma source ion implanted Ti-6Al-4V alloy
z:row.Keyword: Wear of materials|Titanium alloys|Aluminum alloys|Vanadium alloys|Radiation effects|Ion implantation|Nitrogen|Mechanical testing|Surface measurement|Thermal effects|Wear resistance|Dosimetry|Composition effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen implantation by plasma source ion implantation was conducted on Ti-6Al-4V alloy. The wear performance was characterized using a pin-on-disk wear tester and an alpha-step profilometer. Nitrogen concentration depth profiles of implanted samples were studied using a scanning Auger microprobe. It is found that the lowest wear rate in the implanted zone corresponds to the nitrogen concentration peak. By varying the target temperature, the nitrogen concentration profile was engineered to achieve a better wear behavior. The pin-on-disk wear data agree with the expected result.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Machine for fretting wear testing of plasma surface modified materials
z:row.Keyword: Machine design|Wear of materials|Machine components|Mechanical testing|Actuators|Fretting corrosion|Performance|Surface treatment|Ion implantation|Deposition
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Microscopic damage caused by fretting wear is of significant concern in many engineering applications. We report the design and performance of a versatile fretting wear testing machine that uses an electromagnetic actuator under closed-loop control to provide a constant slip amplitude over a wide frequency range. The machine is equipped with a mechanism that allows for gradual sample contact and precise relocation of the stylus. An innovative method for monitoring frictional forces during the course of a test is incorporated. The machine has been successfully applied to materials treated by three types of plasma surface modification: nitrogen ion implantation, thin film alloy deposition and diamond-like carbon film deposition.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Fretting wear testing; Electromagnetic actuator; Nitrogen ion implantation; Thin film alloy deposition; Diamond-like carbon film deposition; Microscopic damage

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear improvement evaluation of non-homogeneous surface modified materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Quantitative evaluation of the improvement of wear properties due to surface modification is complicated by the fact that these properties vary as the modified layer is penetrated. Different methods of evaluation of the same wear test results can yield different or even contrary conclusions. In order to evaluate wear behavior correctly, a wear model that accounts for depth-dependent wear rates is developed and applied to four typical wear tests. It is found that under fixed wear test conditions, the evaluation of wear in surface modified materials depends markedly on the final depth of penetration. This is in contrast to the case of homogeneous materials, where the comparison of the wear behaviour of different materials is largely independent of wear depth. An improvement factor is introduced as the basic quantity for evaluating the wear improvement provided by surface modification. The prediction of the improvement factor from a basic tribology test is carried out for nitrogen ion-implanted Ti-6A1-4V specimens.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Wear properties; Surface modifications

z:row.TitlePrimary: ICRF plugging and radial transport on the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror
z:row.TitleSecondary: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science - 1988, Jun 6-8 1988
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering & Engineering Physics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Recent work on the Phaedrus-B tandem mirror has demonstrated that it is possible to achieve axial plugging (a substantial decrease in ion end loss), a factor of four increase in central cell density (up to n approximately equals 9 × 1012 cm-3), and a decrease in ambipolar radial transport with the application of 'beach' ICRF (launched in the end cell, but resonant in the central cell). A series of experiments has been performed that has demonstrated that (1) the plugging of the ion end loss is a result of the creation of ICRF-enhanced potentials in the end cells and is in agreement with theory; and the increase in density is asssociated with a reduction in ambipolar radial transport.

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Arlington, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a surface modification technique which has been optimized for ion-beam processing of materials. PSII departs radically from conventional implantation by circumventing the line-of-sight restriction inherent in conventional ion implantation. The authors have used PSII to implant cutting tools and dies and have demonstrated substantial improvements in lifetime. Recent results on plasma physics scaling laws, microstructural, mechanical, and tribological properties of PSII-implanted materials are presented.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Dynamic sheath studies in plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science, May 21-23 1990
z:row.Keyword: Plasma Devices -- Applications|Materials--Ion Implantation|Plasmas--Sheaths|Electric Space Charge
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Oakland, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Plasma Source Ion Implantation Group, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Plasma source ion implantation is a non-line-of-sight method for materials processing in which a target is immersed in a plasma and pulse biased to a high negative voltage. A model of the dynamic sheath which forms under these conditions has been developed and applied to planar, cylindrical, and spherical geometries. This model assumes that the transient sheath obeys the Child-Langmuir law for space-charge-limited emission at each instant during the propagation. Ions uncovered by the propagating sheath edge supply the space-charge-limited current. This yields an equation relating sheath edge velocity to position; it can be integrated to obtain the sheath edge position as a function of time. Comparison of results of experimental measurements, the proposed model, and simulation has been performed for the dynamic sheath edge position and target current waveform. Measurements of implanted dose uniformity of wedge-shaped targets were obtained.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma Source Ion Implantation; Child-Langmuir Law; Summary Only

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation - science and technology
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1995 9th International Conference on Surface Modification Technologies, Oct 29-Nov 2 1995
z:row.Keyword: Surface treatment|Plasma applications|Ion implantation|Wear of materials|Corrosion|Metals|Alloys|Fabrication|Semiconductor junctions
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Cleveland, OH, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII), a non-line-of-sight ion surface modification technique, has witnessed a remarkable growth in the understanding of basic science and technology, and consequently a growth in commercial interest in the process. The process has been demonstrated to be effective in improving wear and corrosion of metals and alloys and is presently being explored for the fabrication of semiconductor shallow junctions for the next generation of electronic devices. Considerable interest has been shown in this process by universities, industries, national laboratories, equipment manufacturers, and potential end users of the technology. This paper, drawn largely from research at the University of Wisconsin, reviews the concept of PSII, its advantages and limitations, processing issues and metallurgical effects, potential applications, and the status of this emerging technology.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma source ion implantation; Non line of sight ion surface modification technique
